Text: I booked and paid for a flight on CheapoAir between 2 European cities. Later that day, I saw the carrier offering the same flight, class, limitations on their own website for literally more than 2/3 LESS than what I paid. I provided all the necessary documentation to CoA as instructed under their "Lowest fare guarantee'. They denied my claim because the carrier's website 'is not a US website'. They cite the lack of a US customer service number as a basis. (Note that an effort to use CoA's US phone number resulted in a 53 minute wait, followed by a disconnect, so I had to use online chat anyway.) I don't see the relevance, other than to contrive a way to not meet their advertised promises, However, it gets worse. CoA sent me a hotel coupon to use in conjunction with my (disputed) flight. I decided to use it to shave my loss. Found the hotel I wanted on the dates I needed. I provided all the information including full credit card data. Agreed to CoA terms, hit Confirm, and received a confirmation of - ANOTHER FLIGHT! Nothing about a hotel., No email confirm. Nothing. Now, forced to endure the one hour phone wait, I spoke to a representative who claimed that AmEx had rejected the charge. I called Amex and they denied that. Lie # 1. The CoA rep (still on the phone) told me she would book it directly, but after several minutes, told me the hotel had sold out, and would I like to book somewhere else? That is Lie # 2, because I promptly went to (very reliable) Hotels.com and successfully booked exactly what CoA had originally offered at the same (pre-coupon) price. I also confirmed the booking with the hotel itself. I've booked many air and hotel tickets with CoA, and never had a problem. However, I also never tried to do anything even slightly out of the ordinary, like use a coupon or rely on a guarantee, This is a trust business. Buh-Bye, CheapoAir,

Text: Since Usairways merger with American our service and prices have suffered out of Charlotte. My last experience made me vow to never fly them unless I absolutely had to. My wife and I just returned from a round trip via Delta from Charlotte to Jacksonville, FL. We flew first class cheaper than a coach seat on AA. From the moment we stepped up to the ticket counter in Charlotte until we got our baggage back at the end of the trip, it was amazing to experience the difference in service. The comparison between first class on Delta and first class on AA is amazing. Delta on each leg had chilled water bottles waiting at our seat, fresh blankets, pillows, and the flight attendants came down the aisle and took drink orders on the ground, and seamlessly replaced empty water bottles. Snacks were first rate and included fresh fruit and unique offerings. The entire crew was dressed very sharply, smiled, and actually thanked us for flying with them. They seemed to genuinely enjoy their jobs. Every flight on AA that we've taken since the merger we could hear the flight attendants complaining and they could care less about the service. Not once did passengers get berated by the flight attendants to hurry up so they could have an on time departure by the Delta crews....it is common place on AA. It was as if we stepped back in time when air travel was enjoyable. On each leg of the trip, our luggage was waiting on us when we arrived at baggage claim. AA is lucky to get it to you within 30 minutes. Best decision we've made to switch our business to Delta.

Text: Date: Sun, 27 Feb 2011 12:51:29 -0600 13 hours late , the only positive was the polite and professional Frontier counter ticket attendant hit by a wave of frustrated , tired united passengers at 4am at the Denver terminal.. Once in Minneapolis we were told by Delta that we did not have reservations to fly to Fargo , even though the ticket we received did show a flight , we were then told to see a United ticket agent , and that was in a different terminal . Well off i went , unfortunately the first agent i found was on the phone , he proceeded to tell me , by putting his hand on receiver that he will be on the phone for awhile , i then grabbed my TICKETS and proceeded to the next gate , still not knowing whether we had a flight . The next terminal had an agent dealing with a client , 2 other people were standing just behind the gate having an animated conversation , after 10 mins 1 left and went back to original United gate ..The agent was off the phone , looked at my tickets , reprinted them and said YOU DO have reservations for that flight , go see delta . Off i went to delta again , different terminal again , I was again told by Delta we did not have reservations and I need to go back to United !!!!!!!!!!! At this point I was probably I step away from loosing it , the agent then offered me the United PHONE NUMBER !! ..... After some enormous restraint I insisted she call !! She told me to have a seat , finally I i overheard her mention they had marked an HL or something on the ticket or reservation !!! I have no idea what that meant , shortly after she called us up and asked for our identification !!! we received or tickets and proceeded to our gate ... c 9 then c 10 and then f 1 .... We were a party of 4 , 2 of witch are mid 70 senior citizens , in the 13 hours it took , every time we had to bounce from terminal to terminal they went with us , this was very stress full on them , we had originally boarded united in vegas Friday flight 6659 friday ..I have not checked my credit card statement but we had 2 rooms booked for late check in 130 am saturday morning in Fargo ,ND , as Fargo was not our final destination , so i may find i have been charged for these rooms as well . In Denver the night shift gave us hotel voucher , not used and told use to go to www.unitedapprecition.com for additional information .WE WERE OFFERED 50.00 Travel Voucher !!!!!!! signed SLEEPLESS with UNITED

Well off i went , unfortunately the first agent i found was on the phone , he proceeded to tell me , by putting his hand on receiver that he will be on the phone for awhile , i then grabbed my TICKETS and proceeded to the next gate , still not knowing whether we had a flight . The next terminal had an agent dealing with a client , 2 other people were standing just behind the gate having an animated conversation , after 10 mins 1 left and went back to original United gate ..The agent was off the phone , looked at my tickets , reprinted them and said YOU DO have reservations for that flight , go see delta . Off i went to delta again , different terminal again , I was again told by Delta we did not have reservations and I need to go back to United !!!!!!!!!!! At this point I was probably I step away from loosing it , the agent then offered me the United PHONE NUMBER !! ..... After some enormous restraint I insisted she call !! She told me to have a seat , finally I i overheard her mention they had marked an HL or something on the ticket or reservation !!! I have no idea what that meant , shortly after she called us up and asked for our identification !!! we received or tickets and proceeded to our gate ... c 9 then c 10 and then f 1 .... We were a party of 4 , 2 of witch are mid 70 senior citizens , in the 13 hours it took , every time we had to bounce from terminal to terminal they went with us , this was very stress full on them , we had originally boarded united in vegas Friday flight 6659 friday ..I have not checked my credit card statement but we had 2 rooms booked for late check in 130 am saturday morning in Fargo ,ND , as Fargo was not our final destination , so i may find i have been charged for these rooms as well . Text: I recently returned from 3 weeks in Europe after flying with BA a few times and just wanted to share my experiences I had with the airline. ---- from YVR to LHR: Departed on time, arrived at LHR 20 minutes early. I paid about $100 extra for an exit row seat (28J) and couldn't recommend this more. The seat is located in the first row in Economy, right behind Club World. After takeoff, they close the curtain and due to there being no toilets here, there's no one walking around to disturb you. My seat was right beside the door which kind of protrudes out. This was used as my leg rest for the entire duration of the flight. If you can't afford Premium Economy, this is a really great option. Dinner was a choice of pasta (with feta and tomatoes) or chicken (with rice and veggies). I had the pasta which was actually quite tasty - by no means a five star meal, but not bad for plane food. The chocolate dessert was delicious. After dinner service, lights went out and it was time to sleep. A word of warning - it's extremely cold by the exits. I had a blanket and jacket but I was still shivering throughout the entire flight. In hindsight, I'm not sure why I didn't ask for an extra blanket - I must have been delirious with sleep... Breakfast is served about an hour before landing. It consisted of a fruit muffin, yogurt, and a box of raisins (?!). Not very filling, but oh well. IFE was average - I only watched one movie before going to sleep. The new releases were nothing to get excited about, so it may be wise to bring your own entertainment. BA85 from LHR to YVR: My experience on this flight was similar to the above, except this time I had seat 29K. This is also an exit row seat but in the second row of economy with a missing seat in front which allows you to enter the aisle by walking in front (and not over your seat mates). It was a good seat but not as good as any of the exit row seats in row 28 which just feel more spacious. This flight departed a bit late and arrived 45 minutes late at YVR. I also flew from LHR to BCN (BA486), and AMS to LHR (BA435) on their smaller planes. Both plane interiors looked brand spanking new. I managed to score exit row seats on both these fights as well which was a nice bonus even though the flights were quite short in duration. There's no IFE but they do serve a small snack and free drinks on both flights. I don't know what the snacks were as I declined them on both flights. Overall, a very good experience with BA. They're definitely my airline of choice when flying to, from, and within Europe, especially if I can get an exit row seat on the international flights. Edited: 11:28 pm, July 13, 2015

Text: Has anyone had any experience with Flighthub.com? Do not use www.Flighthub.com. I have been on the phone for 2.5 hours trying to reschedule a flight. Two agents that flat out lied. The first agent (Kay) had me on hold for over an hour then never returned. Total wait time 1 hour 15 minutes. Second agent (Lloyd) said he changed the reservation and updated the itinerary and would email it to me. Total wait time 45 minutes. He emailed the cancelled intinerary and did not save the new updated itinerary. Third agent (so frustrated I forgot her name). She states that there is no reservation and only 2 of the 5 new flights are in the notes. She states that they could not make the reservation and that I should call back on Monday for reservations. Total wait time 30 minutes. If I did not have a $1372.20 credit.....oh by the way, I had to pay $700 in cancellation fees to use the credit, I would never ever use them again.

Text: Hold on to your hand luggage if you are travelling to South Africa on British Airways. Any domestic travel included in your ticket will probably be on South African airline Comair, operating under the British Airways banner. BA/Comair has a “policy” (it happened on both of my flights) of selecting passengers at random and asking them to leave their hand luggage at the door when boarding, as “the cabin is full”. Don’t do it. I did, and had a phone stolen from my bag. When the crew approached me at the door, I asked them if they would stow the bag on board, meaning in the cabin. They said they would. Instead, I ended up collecting my unlocked bag of valuables (minus one) from the carousel in the terminal. To add insult to injury, my bag was well within the regulation size, it fitted comfortably into the overhead locker (on the return trip) and it was all unnecessary as there was plenty of room in the lockers anyway. When I complained to BA at the airport I was told I should not have left valuables in my checked-in luggage! Had I not been so sleep deprived after a long international flight I might have been more circumspect when ambushed by the crew. BA/Comair has not responded to any of the three emails I have sent them. So much for me being accommodating.

Text: Is it just me, or when you look for flights online and some cracking deals come up, they are always the websites that say call us to book. Yet when you call, the prices aren't as they were first advertised and are always a couple of hundred more. Its companies like Dial-A-Flight...... I've tried them a few times to see what deal they can offer, on line it looks good, but once you phone them the deal never seems to exist. They quoted me £850 to Bangkok! Crazy, I managed it for £580 myself for Christmas time.

Text: Has anyone had as much trouble as I have had with Avro Flights. I have recently had cause to get in touch with them to change my booking, I had to wait 35 mins for the call to be answered and at 10p per minute not a cheap call, Once I got through I was told the server was down and I would need to ring again the following following week as they don't open Sunday. I rang in the week and waited 28 minutes for my call to be answered, booking changed, received invoice via email but the details were incorrect, I wrote to them and got nothing back and had to ring again on Saturday, after another 22 minute wait my call was answered, I asked for the booking to be corrected, the operator assured me all was now correct - to date I have not yet received a corrected updated e-ticket which means only one thing I have to ring again as we fly to Greece in 12 days. The thought fills me with dread!!! One thing I can be certain of it didn't take them this long and this many goes to get it right when they took my booking and the payment.

Text: A Qantas Boeing 747 traveling from London "lost power from all four of its main generators 15 minutes away from Bangkok, and the pilot was forced to switch to battery back-up for the landing," The Sydney Morning Herald reports. The Australian newspaper says the Monday incident "is set to prompt a worldwide alert to Boeing 747 operators after the problem was traced to a cracked drip tray under the first-class galley." In a story from this morning, the Morning Herald says "water from the blocked drain collected in a drip tray under the floor. A crack in the drip tray caused the water to leak into electrical wiring. Each of the plane's four engines has its own generator, but the water shorted out the aircraft's power supply." David Cox, Qantas' executive general manager responsible for engineering, tells The Australian "it was just like tipping a glass of water into your stereo." Dr. Arvind Sinha, director of aerospace at RMIT University in Melbourne, explains to the Morning Herald that "the engines have their own independent power source and the steering is operated by a hydraulic pump system, but the critical issues are the navigation and communication systems that you need to find your way to a runway to land." Colin Adams of the Australian and International Pilot's Association says the Qantas crew and passengers were "lucky" that the plane was not far out over open water when the incident occurred, according to the London Daily Mail. "In that situation you have a minimum of 30 minutes before you lose power to the flight instruments," Adams tells the Morning Herald. "After that the only idea that you have of airspeed and where you are in relation to what's around you is what you can see out of the window. There is no written procedure for what happens in that situation -- it's the pilot and his wits. If you were a long way from an airfield at night it would be an extremely hazardous situation. If you were in cloud you would not know where the ground was and you could end up in an extremely dangerous situation." The 747-400 is now back in service for Qantas, according to The Associated Press. "As a precaution, Qantas has inspected its entire B747-400 fleet and all of these aircraft have been cleared to fly," Qantas executive John Borghetti tells The Telegraph of London. Posted at 09:09 AM/ET, Jan 10, 2008 in International carriers, USAToday

Text: EasyJet have announced they will close their base in Madrid this October, pulling all eight aircraft out and redeploying them elsewhere across Europe. Although only 20% of services will be lost within the next year, EasyJet are still selling tickets as normal through the winter season with no route or frequency cuts at all other than Manchester and schedules still show early morning departures and late night arrivals in Madrid, which shows that aircraft is based there. Why are they still selling these flights when us who take only little interest in the aviation industry know they won't happen but others less so will not? I'd say for the time being people DO NOT BOOK EASYJET FLIGHTS TO/FROM MADRID POST OCTOBER 2012 AS THERE'S A CHANCE IT MAY NOT FLY! Give it a couple of weeks or so unless anything happens before hand. Anybody remember when they closed East Midlands flights? They sold them and people were booking them when EasyJet knew they wouldn't fly at that time. Same seems to be happening here! Edited: 4:17 am, June 23, 2012

Text: Hello, just wondering which travel insurance you guys use that really work? In the fall we had a two week vacation to Europe, involved four United flights. First got canceled, ergo the second one we missed. Took three other ones instead. On the trip back two flights were planned. Both got canceled even though they were confirmed about three times. Had to take another airline back, skipped last flight and took the train back instead. Had paid for the overseas flight extra for economy plus seats and of course didn't get them since the flight got canceled and we flew with another carrier. Paid $700 for travel insurance, didn't see a penny. Thanks, Undine

Text: I flew to Stockholm with Finnair 3 weeks ago; on arriving after 8pm I found my baggage damaged but no one around to report it to. On flying back to London a few days later I went to report the damage to a Finnair employee in Stockholm; I was told that she couldn't do anything & to report it in Helsinki where I would get my connecting flight back to London; speaking to the Finnair employee In Helsinki I was told as I didn't have my case with me as it had been automatically transferred to the connecting flight that she couldn't help me & to report the damage in London when I had my case; back in London I am then informed by the 3rd Finnair employee that I had been given the wrong information & that it should have been dealt with in Stockholm; I was then told to speak to the baggage people at Heathrow who gave me an information sheet to email the company who deals with Finnair's damaged luggage with the photos & luggage tag; I subsequently didn't hear from them so I called up to be told they couldn't help me & to call Finnair customer services. After speaking to the 4th Finnair employee I am told to fill in the feedback form; that was almost 2 weeks ago; I have not heard anything or been asked for anymore information. Any ideas on who to contact to speed up the process of getting my baggage repaired/making a claim? I will be flying again soon so any help is most appreciated!

Text: I flew with Easyjet last year for the first (and last!!!) time. We actually got as far as boarding the plane when the pilot announced that he would not fly the aircraft as he had an ear ache. We were told that an alternative pilot could not be found and that we would not be flying out until the next morning. We were put up in a hotel and given a letter stating that we were entitled to 250 euros compensation each under EU legislation. On our return, I emailed EJ requesting the compensation and a refund for our first nights accomodation in Spain, which we had booked via EJ. The hotel money was refunded but I am yet to receive the EU compensation. I sent a letter in March requesting it and have still heard nothing. Has anybody else had this much of a fight for the compensation? It's like getting blood out of a stone!!!

Text: i'v never saw a company that so disrespect her clients. i bought a ticket from israel to usa which cost a-l-o-t of money.since I'm from israel I'm not familiar with there coin (GBP) or something like that, it looks just like the Euro sign so i was sure i was paying in Euro. a few min after i realized it was not Euro so it means i paid 1000 more (nis) than i thought, i tried to find an email to contect them right away to cancel my flight befot the confirmation of the ticket, but there was no email in the web just phone number in Europe that i cant call. i sent them a massage on facebook which was my only option, beggin them to get back to me..in the mean time i sent an email to paypal asking to not aprove the charge...no one was answering me.... just the next day edreams answered to my facebbok, that i can't cancel the flight and there's nothing to do. in there website they wrote black on white the you can cancel the flight for 25 GBP... the only answer i got from them was trough facebook, and i was begging for an email adresss i could contact and explain, or at least get a better explaintion...but nothing i dont mind paying the fee cuse anyway if ill book a diffrent flight+ the fee it will be cheaper than what i paid in edreams! it's not even the gratest flight there are stops in the middle so i could find a cheaper flight for shore, it was an onest mistake that i was reading the sign wrong, i tried to cancel a less then 5 min after, but nothing... now I'm crying every time i remember this, I'm a student that can't afford this amount for a flying ticket.. i need to work 3 months for this kind of amount..my all vacation rouin...i will never book frim them again!

Text: Just when you think that after years of traveling virtually every domestic airline & a few international ~ you've suffered nearly all of the possible inconveniences ~ a new one comes along. Allegiant Flight was 45 minutes late taking off from Memphis because they were "still loading baggage." We arrived in Las Vegas 1 hour past Arrival time. As we landed, the announcement was made to lower all window shades & place seat belts in seats, as the plane was scheduled to depart again quickly. Waited 45 minutes @ Baggage Claim. No bags. Passengers flooded Allegiant Office, where it was "determined" that the baggage was not in LAS, nor was it in MEM. & No there's not another flight from MEM today. Maybe tomorrow? By the time most had spent 20 minutes filling out Lost Luggage Forms, I (not one to give up easily) asked an Allegiant Associate if they were sure they had checked all possible cargo areas? @ This point, I'm thinking:: "Surely they didn't put a whole flight's luggage on a plane to ???" That would make no sense. It HAS to be HERE!!! She made a phone call:: "Has anyone checked the middle cargo compartment?" Held for a few minutes. Then "Yaaaaaaay!!!!" Duh . . . 1 more hour before we could retrieve it from the belt. So 2 hours 45 minutes of wasted gambling time. Bet I could have lost @ least $245 by now 😜 You would think they would at least hand out Free Drink Tickets, as we were all dry / parched / & way overdue for 1st cocktail. No. I didn't even hear "I'm sorry for your trouble / wait / delay / stress."

Text: This is in the news again. The government has ordered a review. "The Treasury said that the 'extensive' review would make sure that shoppers got the discounts they are entitled to." The simplest thing of course would be to make the practice illegal. "VAT relief at airports is intended to cut prices for those travellers - not be a windfall gain for shops," said Chancellor George Osborne."But many people could be paying over the odds for their purchases because the government's VAT concession isn't passed on. This is simply unacceptable." http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-35197809

Text: If flying and you like grease get the Bolognese and Gnocchi it's absolutely vile. And you are paying for it. It bears no resemblance to their adverts. If they were a bank then their would be mismanagement companies after them. Worse still got return flight at 21:30 so will be starved by we get to Manchester. Sum up, don't bother wasting your money on food. Positive is great cabin crew and comfortable seats(in extra leg room) will fly with them again but never buy meals in advance

Text: I'd really like some help with this, if I could, please... I'm looking at travelling first class on an A380 from Australia to Europe and I'm trying to decide between the first class product offered by Qantas and that offered by Emirates. Initial research seems to reveal that the EK suites are more private with sliding doors and the QF suites are more open. But I would really like to make a decision that is as informed as possible as this is a large out-lay, so I am hoping someone might be able to provide a few 'first-hand' pros and cons for each airline's first class offerings, please. By the way, there will be two of us travelling and would prefer the centre side-by-side seats rather than two (one behind the other) on the side.

Text: Given the chaos of the new carry-on rules and security issues with electronics, I'd like to remind everyone that there are ways to have things pick-up at your house and delivered at your destination - fully insured. And LOCKED. I put this link up on the Orlando forum, but I guess it worth doing here as well. I pack and ship my stuff via FedEx or UPS all the time for vacation trips. It doesn't work for business trip and shipping anything like a laptop would be rather risky, more for what's on it than the laptop itself which can be insured - The contents can't! usxp.com/products_and_services/… There are other services available and many folks who want to have their own skis or golf clubs have been using them for sometime. Just google 'luggage delivery service'. You can also check sites like Travel&Liesure and Travel&Holiday for more resources. I like traveling 'luggage free', but it only works for non-perishables, and when you'll be arriving at a responsible destination, like a good hotel/resort or villa rental. Just a suggestion. It may destress some of the travel restrictions - except the laptop one!

Text: Just my luck. It's my Daughter's 18th today. Had a meal planned to celebrate for ages now and my flight booked months ago. Got up at 0530 this morning to get ready to go to the airport and had a text from Easyjet to tell me the flight was concelled. Blooming heck I said, or words t that effect, what am I going to do now? To top it off I forgot that they sent me a mail ages ago changing the flight to 1020 so not only have they cancelled I got up two hours early:-((((( Not blaming EZY for the horrendous snow but I tried to call customer services at 0600 and was on the phone for 30 mins before giving up. I wanted to see if I could change the flight to go to MAN then catch a train which you can't seem to do online, only reschedule the flight or get a refund. Anyway I have managed to get on KLM (€220 !) but not until 2100 tonight. There was a flight at 1500 but after procrastinating about what to do and hanging on the phone to Easyjet that quickly filled up as KLM also cancelled their morning flights to and from EDI. Moral of this story is don't hang about in these situations. Carpe diem and grab the next available flight before some other bugg3r does. Anyway will miss the meal but these things happen. Never had a flight cancelled before due to weather but it would have to be today of all days.At least EZY managed to let me know by text and e-mail BEFORE I left for Schiphol. By the way flgihts to Glasgow for the next few days were over €500 on KLM. I only wanted a seat not an executive jet!! Moan over ;-)

Text: In North America recently my Air Canada flight to China was cancelled. I was issued with 2 new tickets on other airlines, in the form of Flight Interruption Manifests (FIM). Delta accepted the 1st FIM and flew me from Boston to Los Angeles. There, China Southern refused to accept the 2nd FIM, which would have allowed me to reach my final destination in Guangzhou. I was left stranded in Los Angeles by China Southern. Has anyone else experienced the same difficulty, whether on China Southern or another airline, when their original flight was cancelled?
Annotator A Text: [In North America recently my Air Canada flight to China was cancelled. ]I was issued with 2 new tickets on other airlines, in the form of Flight Interruption Manifests (FIM). Delta accepted the 1st FIM and flew me from Boston to Los Angeles. There, China Southern refused to accept the 2nd FIM, which would have allowed me to reach my final destination in Guangzhou.[ I was left stranded in Los Angeles by China Southern. ]Has anyone else experienced the same difficulty, whether on China Southern or another airline, when their original flight was cancelled?
Annotator B Text: In North America recently my Air Canada flight to China was cancelled.[ I was issued with 2 new tickets on other airlines, in the form of Flight Interruption Manifests (FIM). I was left stranded in Los Angeles by China Southern. Has anyone else experienced the same difficulty, whether on China Southern or another airline, when their original flight was cancelled?

Text: Wondering if anyone has any views on which JFK hotels have the most frequent/reliable airport shuttle service. It's hard to find detailed information on hotel websites, and I can see from some tripadvisor reviews that some hotels only have hourly shuttle services (in which case it's probably worth getting a taxi for early morning flights, and I'll price that in when making my choice). Last time I had a 1 night stopover the hotel only operated a small minivan to get to JFK in the early morning (despite using a bigger vehicle the night before), and we had to wait over 10 minutes for the driver to try to squeeze all the passengers and luggage on, with some luggage/passengers ending up on other people's laps, and some left behind.

Text: I know Jetstar regularly get a slating for their delays and bad service, so thought it was only fair I shared the excellent experience we had with them recently. We flew Christchurch NZL to Narita Airport, Tokyo via the Gold Coast Airport. The flights were on time going over, no issues with delays or connections. The flight was delayed an hour coming back, but apart from that we had no issues with onwards connections, lost bags etc. The planes were lovely and service great. The thing that impressed us most was regarding our request to have luggage on the way back. We had booked a while back when they had a 2:1 special (2 fly for price of 1). We booked our basic flights ex Chch. Over the next few weeks we got several emails changing details of our flight. For the most part these were tiny changes: change of terminal, flights changing times by 5-10 minutes (in our favour), however, one of the changes was canning the return flight to Chch and putting us on a flight to Auckland, then a domestic flight to Chch. We didn't have any choice but to accept this as our trip was on quite a tight timeframe. Later we decided that we wanted to have one person with 10kg baggage on the way back to allow for a few souvenirs we planned to get. When we went to do this online, we found that it would cost us $98 (which we were prepared to pay) plus $15 more because of the domestic flight we now had through the change to their scheduling. We decided to wait until the airport and ask them there to waive the $15 as it was not our choice to do that leg. The lady at the airport counter spent quite a bit of time going through our booking history, then she handed us our boarding passes and said no problem. I pulled out my cc to pay for the Narita-AKL baggage and she said there was no charge for that either. We had asked for one person to have 10kg and she loaded 15kg baggage on both our tickets for free. We thought that was pretty good and were happy with that! When we got onto the Gold Coast-Auckland leg of our return flight we discovered we had exit row seats and then when the food trolley came round, the hostess informed us we each had $10 voucher for food. This was our first time flying long haul with a LCC. Even without the freebies we got as compensation for the change of return flight, we found it a good experience and would happily fly Jetstar long haul again out of NZ/Australia.

Text: I see a lot of complaints and dissatisfaction by people who have used online reservations websites, and most of the problems people have had appear to be the purchasers' own fault. The reality here, of course, is that there really is nothing unbusiness-like or underhanded, nor are there any "bait and switch" tactics in what these sites offer or what they charge as YOU authorize the total amount of charges which you agree to pay when you "submit." It isn't worth complaining if YOUdon't exercise reasonable care -- and READ THE FINE PRINT beforehand -- when using such sites. One thing to always be sure of is that you see a physical address for a legitmate place of business and someone whom you can contact should a problem arise. Without that, the website may well be a scam or dishonest.

Text: Here is a copy of a letter I sent Cheapoair. I am trying to have the police in New York file criminal charges. They say I have a credit for $1833, but won't let me use it. 8/29/07 I am a physician working in Walnut Creek California. I bought (11/ 6/2006) three United Airline tickets ($1833 visa receipt is attached) from Cheapoair (internet site located in New York) to fly from San Francisco to Cancun on January 20th, 2007. Due to changes at my job, I cancelled my flights well in advance of the departure date. I was told I would now have a monetary credit (minus a $100 penalty per ticket) that could be used for one year. I called and reconfirmed this numerous times. I have been trying to make new reservations for over three months now. At first I tried to use the credit to go to New York (see emails), now I have been simply trying to rebook my original itinerary (SFO to CUN). Every representative tells me I have a credit for $1833, and that they can make me a reservation, but when I go to book the flights they say they have to talk with their booking department and will get back to me. They never do! I have cell phone record of hours of conversation time. I have also sent numerous emails, including a final warning that I would be filing a criminal complaint. This case is simply a matter of fraud. They have $1833 of my money, but won’t give me my money back or let me purchase tickets. Cheapoair booking number: ###### phone number: ########## United ticket numbers: #############, #############, ############# Names of Cheapoair reps I have spoken to: Russell, Gina, Nevin and Stephanine—both promised repeatly they would get back to me, and never did. Sincerely,

Text: According to www.seatguru.com AA 763s come in two different first class seat configurations: The 767-300 ver. 1 (763) has regular seats. The 767-300 ver. 2 (763) has lie-flat seats. I can't see a way to tell which configuration you will end up with when booking a flight. The AA reservation system will just say that it's a 763 - no mention of specifics about type of seats, etc. Is there a way to tell? (besides calling the airline and debating the point with a rep on the phone...) If I am going to pay for first class, I want to be sure that I'm getting a comfortable seat!

Text: Based on airlines you have personally flown, which would be your favourites? I have flown Qantas, Jetstar, Virgin Blue, Pacific blue, Air Nz, Continental, Tiger Airways, Air Asia, Thai, Singapore, Vietnam Air, Bangkok Airways, Freedom Air, Emitates, British Airways, United, Emirates, Easyjet and probably a few more I can't remember. Singapore would be my fave because of the amazing crew who will do abosolutly anything, nothing is too much for them. Entertainment system is top notch, with large screens, and plenty of movies, Tv, games etc, there is something for everyone! Another thing I love about SIA is the legroom. I don't know the stats but even in economy I feel there is much more leg room than other carriers. And finally the food. Sia by far IMO has the best food of an airline. Second for me goes to Emirates with Thai a close 3rd. What are your favourite airlines and why?

Text: I plan to travel from Edinburgh to a European destination via Dublin outbound and Belfast International inbound. The reason for not flying direct is based on price and lack of availability. Text: Just wondering if anyone has experienced anything like this. We were booked onto a TAP flight from Heathrow to Lisbon, Lisbon to Miami in July 2015 as a party of 9. Two different groups applied for their Esta's. An email was received to say Authorised after the initial word on application said Pending. We could not book in online, it came up as check in at airport. We arrived at Heathrow at 02:30 for a 6am flight. The passport machine would not let us check in. We were directed to different desks around the airport, the final one being the Special Assistance desk. There was already a family with a problem at the desk and there was no senior members of staff to help us. We were told there was a problem with our Esta. We promptly got the Esta number up on our mobile devices but the check in staff said it was too late to book 9 people in and closed the flight!!! We were told to go to the ticket desk and buy new tickets! There was no staff from TAP airlines to help us. The manager eventually came back from the gate and agreed to talk to us. After much discussion we were booked on United flights the following day. Our party of 9 were split up into 5 and 4. 4 going first via Newark, then 5 going 5 hours later via Houston. They would not discuss how we wanted the party split resulting in my daughter's friend flying with our other family members. We were due to arrive in Miami on Sat afternoon but got there Monday morning. We were at Heathrow for 32 hours with children. Tap would not help us with a hotel, meals, nothing! We have a case open with the CAA but at this point TAP are saying we did not have the correct documents. We did have them and produced them, there was no-one to help us at Heathrow. We had no different documents on the Sunday when we were allowed to fly with United. Our argument is that there should have been someone there to help us. An immigration officer at the airport said our problem could have been sorted out by the airline in minutes. Has anyone got any advice on this? TIA ---

Text: Just wanted to warn people not to waste your time with Delta's "Best Fare Guarantee" that they supposedly offer. I went through all the steps, had a perfectly valid claim, on the same day, and was denied. This was their response: "Your reservation is booked in ?V? and ?T? classes of service. At the time of our research at www.priceline.com, we were able to locate a lower fare of $(edited) per passenger. However, the classes of service were ?V? and ?T.? therefore, we must respectfully decline your request." I politely asked that they re-consider, sent a screenshot from Priceline's website and even offered to help them find it (because it's still there and very easy to locate) when I was given another copy and pasted response telling me to read their terms and conditions. I've read them several times. Dear Delta, please just remove the program all together if you don't want to honor it! No one is making you have this program! Don't waste our time! Has anyone ever gotten one of these approved? Now that I'm researching it, I've yet to come across anyone who has been approved. I'll definitely be looking at other options next time I fly, not because of the lack of a price match, but because of the awful customer service I have received. Imagine if something really went wrong and you needed something!

Text: My partner and I recently flew back from Barcelona to Heathrow with BA. The flight was delayed by 2.5 hours, resulting in our getting into Heathrow after midnight, when all public transport other than taxis had ceased running. During the flight, we were told on two occasions by crew that if passengers were to take a taxi home, this would be refunded in full by the airline on presentation of a receipt. On arrival, we received a quote from a London black cab for £85-90 to North London. This would normally be an excessive expense for us, but as it was 12.30am we took the taxi in order to get home quickly (and in the understanding that reimbursement would be forthcoming). The final fare ended up being £97. However, on making a claim and presenting our taxi receipt, we were informed by BA's Customer Relations department that we would only be refunded £50 as the full amount was considered 'beyond reasonable' and it would be 'unfair to other customers' to make an exception. After querying this further - and stressing that passengers were explicitly told that they would be 'fully' refunded for any taxi journeys - we finally learnt (via a response from the airline's Twitter account!) that the maximum compensation given for transport is £50. I wondered if any others have experienced something similar? I think it's fair to say that we and the other passengers were misled by BA, who promised something only to fail to deliver, leaving us considerably out of pocket. They also appear to be completely oblivious to the actual cost of a standard taxi from Heathrow to London! If anybody has any suggestions on alternative channels for proceeding with this, it would be much appreciated. I have already considered raising it with the CAA. ----

Text: After reading up on the Internet and been unreliably informed by our travel agent that our names being transposed on our etickets i.e first name as your surname and last name as your first name we decided that it should not be a problem. Turned up to check in and were not able to be checked in on a virgin flight to bali from auckland. Apparently Virgin cannot alter the booking only the travel agent (who is of course was closed at 4am) can. The only option was to purchase another ticket!! We made it in the end but our ticket home has the same problem!!so trying to sort that now. My advice book directly through the airline - it may cost a little more but at least you can sort ticket issues!

Text: Their customer service is terrible, and deceptive. When we had to cancel a ticket, they were very unclear about the fees, and lead us to believe that we would have a $150 balance left over after canceling, when, in reality, the entirety of the balance was absorbed by fees. It left a bad taste in my mouth that they made an extra $25 on me canceling, when the end result was me being left with nothing. I would have rather been told there was no possibility of changing the ticket because of airline change fees were too high. Getting a straight answer out of their customer service was impossible.

Text: We was booked to fly home from PRG-EMA at 21:55 on the 14/6/09. At 23:00 we was told by leaflet it was cancelled "due to crew out of hours." It did not leave East Midlands. We was all put up in a airport hotel with breakfeast. And it stated we will fly out on PRG-EMA/STD. at 11:20 the next day 15/6/09. On getting up we went to the airport at 8-00 only to find this flight cancelled as well. We was told to report back at 9:30 when we was told there is a plane coming from Luton for us and we will leave at 13:30. We left at 14.15 over 16 hours late on what we was told by easyjet cabin crew as a rescue flight. On getting home I rang Easyjet to find out about the 250 euro's each in compensation only to be told the flights where not cancelled but rescheduled so we cannot claim. Is there any point in emailing them with a claim or am I p****** against the wind. ------.

Text: Flying yesterday from Istanbul to Stockholm (TK 1795), I tried to check in on-line the day before. I was surprised that on-line check in failed because "you have been allocated an exit row seat". I had not requested an exit row seat, nor made any seat request, expecting to do that at check-in. The airline had no way of knowing my state of health and physical ability, apart from having flown TK three times previously in the last month, none of these flights being in an exit row. At Ataturk, I mentioned this to a supervisor, and she just handed me the boarding pass and shrugged her shoulders when I asked for an explanation. Incidentally at on-line check in I wasn't able to change the seat allocation, and by the time I got to Ataturk the plane was full, so it was lucky I was able-bodied, and that my able-bodiedness was not required. Can anyone explain this "method" of seat allocation ?

Text: This might be an inappropriate question to ask on this forum, but I'm not sure where else to post it - and my family and I cannot figure out a decent solution to the problem. Here it is: I have friends and family members who can't or won't be bothered to mail presents (and money is not the problem). They save them up for when I visit and then give them to me then, expecting me to take them back on the plane. Sometimes these gifts are quite bulky; and, as I travel lightly (almost always without checked luggage, and usually with just a back-pack), they never fit into my luggage. On one occasion I ended up checking my backpack to bring the present on board as a carry-on; on another occasion, a family member mailed me the present (and didn't tell the giver that she was doing this). I've kind of had it, and would frankly prefer not to receive anything rather than have to pay $25 to check luggage or put another family member out. I would greatly appreciate any tactful suggestion about how to handle this situation.

Text: I plan to travel from Mumbai to JFK via LHR in December. The 9 and half hour BA flight from Mumbai reaches LHR at 7.10AM. I have two options from thereon. I can take the 8.30 flight to JFK, reaching at 11.10 AM or the 10.00 AM flight to JFK reaching 12.40 PM. I am entitled to lounge access at LHR. I plan to fly economy. Which of the two flights from LHR should be preferred? The second one will allow me to relax a bit in the lounge. However I am a bit worried that the 10.00 AM flight would likely to be more full with more passengers connecting to it. I sure like some empty seats near mine!

Text: I know that one should never go back and check the prices after a fare has been purchased but I did and saw that the fare had dropped by $250 since I booked the flights yesterday, I called US Airways to ask if there was any way I could avail of the lower fare and since I was within 24 hours, I was able to cancel (without penalty) and re-purchase at the lower fare on a non-refundable ticket. Funds should be re-deposited into my account within 7/10 days ! Good to know !

Text: After returning from Mexico with Thomas Cook in the Premier Cabin it has to be stated that the Premier Cabin is NOT WORTH the money. The benifits of the Premier Cabin are several: *Dedicated check in (no waiting). *Complimentry drinks. *More leg room. *First on (and off) at your destination. THATS it.... You are told you will get a choice of meals; (chicken OR beef is the choice). Your luggage has Priority Hold labels fitted: (they mean nothing). Extra film channels: (the whole plane got them). When returning to the UK (G/Gow) my baggage ends up at Manchester. The Premier Cabin has 49 seats @ £300 per return trp which equals £14700, A LOT OF EXTRA MONEY FOR THOMAS COOK.... Then when you try to get in touch with them to talk about your grievances, they dont want to know, as they have your money and dont seem to care about customer service.. After nearly 2 weeks I am still waiting a response to several emails to them. CONCLUSION: Go on holiday with ANY ONE BUT THOMAS COOK.......

Text: The airline pilots' union Balpa says it is lifting the threat of strike action at Virgin Atlantic which could have affected travellers' summer holidays. Balpa said it had secured a new offer from the airline, which it will present to its members in the coming weeks. Details of the fresh offer have not been announced. Last month, Virgin pilots voted overwhelmingly to go on strike for the first time in the airline's history in a dispute about pay. Balpa general secretary Jim McAuslan said: "Pilots have never wished to inconvenience the travelling public, especially those looking forward to summer holidays. We have therefore lifted the threat of strike action." Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson had warned that the threatened strike would leave an "indelible scar" on the airline.

We have therefore lifted the threat of strike action." Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson had warned that the threatened strike would leave an "indelible scar" on the airline.

We have therefore lifted the threat of strike action." Virgin boss Sir Richard Branson had warned that the threatened strike would leave an "indelible scar" on the airline.

Text: i fly with china airlines from Los angeles to taipei with connecting flight to jakarta almost 20 hours flight. it was a very dissapointed experience from my 20 years flying experience. i'm a travel addict, i will travel at least 2 times a year to all over the world, n i ve been used many airlines, from asian airlines, european, even from arabian airlines..but china airlines is the biggest dissapointment. their ground staff are mean..never smile, no cooperation at all..i've never seen someone in service business that never give a smile...even starbuck who sell a cup of coffee give a smile everytime they serve. i travel with two small childrens, i asked her nicely that, if possible can she gave me a four in a row seats so we can be seating together..she respond NO without looking or even try to look for the seats..so in the end i've to beg other passangers on the aircraft so we can be seated together and the stewardess do not bother to help me out with this. and after all my documents finished and i received my boarding passes , i said thank you to her but she didn't respond or look at me..just pretend to be busy. at the boarding gate they call for a traveller with a small children to be onboard before the rest, so like i usually do ,i came forward and show them my ticket and my children but alas they rejected me at the gate and said what they mean is children under 2 years old. what is wrong with this peoples, what is the differences between 2 years old and 4 years old children ? so that's it ! this will be my last flight with china airlines.. i call my travel agent and said to them not to offer me this airlines again, better offer me a twin otter plane from some village airlines than this so called four star airlines...they do not deserve it

Text: I recently booked a round trip from Zurich to Sydney with Bravofly. After reading some of the posts I now realise this was not the best idea. I booked for me, my wife and a friend and about a month ago received an email sating that the return flight home was cancelled and that my options were; Accept a schedule change and they would request this with the airliner; Apply for a refund subject to approval. I requested a schedule change and the friend I booked for got an instant reply with the new schedule yet for my wife and I it has been a month and Bravofly keep saying 'your request has been forwarded to the schedule change department' and we will be notified. Most of the emails have been in poor english and a lot just have absolutely no response. Can anyone help me with anything I can do, words I can say to fix this problem?

Text: We have a few options at the moment in booking a Melbourne to London flight for Dec/Jan this year. Etihad had the best return fares but have disappeared at the moment, with the next best being Malaysian, followed closely by BA and Cathay Pacific. For single flights, we can get the same prices, flying over with Singapore and returning with Etihad, BA, or Qantas. The costs for the two one-way fares is pretty similar to the return fares. Up until today I was pretty sure we would go with the one way fares, mainly because Singapore has such a good name and we could then try (mixed reviews) Etihad on the way home, or Qantas if we wanted the old faithful. What changed today was that Cathay has come into the game with a very competitive return fare and I have heard that they are on a par with Singapore. If this is right, it would seem that taking the Cathay return fare would be the best option. Would love to hear any opinions from those who have comparisons or experiences with any of the above. Thanks. ----

Text: I paid $80.00 for flight insurance from Access America. I had flown to Hollywood, FL from NYC to be with my husband for Christmas while he visited his elderly father in the hospital. I planned to fly back after a week. Then my father-in-law died two days after Christmas. Now Access America is refusing my claim. This is outrageous. Access America refused my claim because my father-in-law's death was "either known to you or likely to happen." I had no idea he was going to die when he did or I wouldn't have made the flight reservations in the first place. My husband and I are self-employed so one of us had to get back to the business. We couldn't both stay there for the days, weeks or months he might have lasted. When he passed away it became more important for me to stay with my husband. Now Access America is telling me my only recourse is arbitration, which involves a fee and court appearance. Access America is in the business of taking people's money. ----- ---------- NYC, NY

Text: I recently flew with Thomson and would never do so again. I flew with one checked bag at a meagre 20kg, and my usual hand luggage bag on wheels. All was perfectly fine on the way OUT (hand luggage was given a cursory glance and declared to be fine), but coming home was a different story. The officials at Crete weighed my hand luggage and found it to be overweight. I had NEVER had hand luggage weighed before, even on the Thomson flight out. I was sent to a different desk in order to check in my hand luggage as a second bag for the hold. I was told this would be €25 and begrudgingly agreed to this, pointing out that this had NOT been a problem on the way over for the SAME bag. Upon reaching the desk, I was told that ON TOP of the €25 I had to pay an amount per every kilo this bag weighed. I was presented with a total fee for checking in a very small hand-luggage sized bag, of....wait for it....€133! The staff were rude, dismissive and told me this was Thompson policy and the airline was rigorous in its baggage checks. This obviously only applies on your return flight, where you have no other option of leaving stuff, and struggle to understand the language and make yourself understood. I felt bullied and was reduced to tears. During discussion, I was told my flight was completely full - it was not. I was also told if I didn't pay up, the €133 would be taken from the pocket of the lady working on the Thomson desk! (really?!) There were other people queuing, all bitterly upset with the surcharges dumped on them for the return flight only. I eventually rectified the situation by donating my beach towels and books to Thomson, and wearing approx 4kg of my clothes, thus saving myself €133. Hideous end to a lovely week, all faith in Thomson GONE. PS credit to the amazing cabin crew staff who looked after me on the return flight - i could have hugged you all for your kindness.

Text: I booked a round trip ticket (w/ 5 days in between departures) for 360.00 USD on virgin air. I heard wonderful things: "Its modern" "Everyone is so friendly" "Free wifi" "great in flight entertainment" " Electrical outlets at every seat!" I was sold! I thought I got a great deal ( never flown to nyc before and 360.00 seems like a steal) But now, im a little nervous. Maybe I've been reading too many reviews by 'difficult passangers' but I have heard : There is only free wifi on flights from sfo to jfk, all others must bay 13.00 usd most outlets don't work ( was a common complaint I've heard..) no free inflight drinks or snacks ( not even water?) inflight movies and ther entertainment are available for an undisclosed fee. Now, im not by any means a difficult passanger. I pay attention during the safety lecture, bring my own food and drinks as well as a book or two and most of all, I realize the flight attendants are there for safety and not to be a 'sky waitress' But after reading/ hearing all that I can't help but feel like I got a bad deal. I adore jetblue and I feel like I should have booked with them, I could have had a free cold drink mid flight and some basic cable incase I tire of reading. Im traveling with my elderly mother who walks with a cane and I have heard that VA may or may not allow an attendant with the person who is pre boarding. I worry that she may not want to board with out me or she may have a hard time navigating the rows alone. Do you think a attendant would be willing to walk slowly behind her incase she loses her balance? Im really just looking for some real experiences from agreeable passengers who have flown VA and, to see if I got the great deal I thought I did. Thanks for your help. ( and honesty!)

Maybe I've been reading too many reviews by 'difficult passangers' but I have heard : There is only free wifi on flights from sfo to jfk, all others must bay 13.00 usd most outlets don't work ( was a common complaint I've heard..) no free inflight drinks or snacks ( not even water?) inflight movies and ther entertainment are available for an undisclosed fee. Now, im not by any means a difficult passanger. I pay attention during the safety lecture, bring my own food and drinks as well as a book or two and most of all, I realize the flight attendants are there for safety and not to be a 'sky waitress' But after reading/ hearing all that I can't help but feel like I got a bad deal. I adore jetblue and I feel like I should have booked with them, I could have had a free cold drink mid flight and some basic cable incase I tire of reading. Im traveling with my elderly mother who walks with a cane and I have heard that VA may or may not allow an attendant with the person who is pre boarding. I worry that she may not want to board with out me or she may have a hard time navigating the rows alone.] Do you think a attendant would be willing to walk slowly behind her incase she loses her balance? [Im really just looking for some real experiences from agreeable passengers who have flown VA and, to see if I got the great deal I thought I did. Thanks for your help. ( and honesty!)]

Text: I travel on Firefly (the "budget" airline under Malaysian Airlines) for the convenience of flying out of Subang Airport. Recently, I opted for the 'taxi' booking to add on to my travel booking from the Firefly website. Let me tell you - NEVER opt for this. The airlines charged me MYR6 and it is really for no good reason and it was not explained clearly in the website. I was under the impression that "for my convenience" I could book a cab to get to the airport and this was the cab fare. It is not. It is merely to have the cab company call you to ask whether you need a cab!!! Which you can do for free on your own. So, in addition to the MYR6 you pay to the airlines, you will need to fork out the metered fare plus MYR10 (because you booked the cab as opposed to flagging it down at a cab stand). Do not get cheated by Firefly by opting for this "taxi service". I demanded a refund from Firefly and was promptly told I can complain by sending in an email to the airlines!!! How's that for service??!!

Text: I have been a Life Member of Qantas Club for years but generally, these days, choose other airlines. For all the smoke and mirrors, Qantas is very ho-hum , ergo, dull and boring. After a series of serious in-flight incidents, the proud kangaroo has had a bit of PR disaster. While Qantas has not had an accident/incident where people died, tarnished is the operative word for them. They are gradually whittling away any benefits at all. Recently I booked with their subsidiary, Jetstar, Sydney - Honolulu return with business options. Here, the add-ons they normally charge to go cattle are generally included. I have a cattle class Sydney-Brisbane return with them as well and that has add-on costs galore. My real beef is the dreadful Jetstar website and lack of connection with that of Daddy QANTAS. In spite of endless patience and a very fast Internet connection, the Jetstar site is woefully slow and has severe Alzheimer's! The site continues to insist that I have no booking for my international leg although I have a confirmed itinerary and a booking number: absolutely a denial that such a booking exists. A call to their customer service department took two days to get through! It kept ringing out or I got a number unreachable message. When I did connect, I was assured there was such a booking but not according to my profile. However, the domestic booking is there! Go figure! With well over 400,000 frequent flyer points, Qantas has a couple of reward options for flight redemptions but of course, taxes can be extreme so one might just as well buy a ticket anyway. To sum up, Qantas is a dead duck and I avoid them generally. My loyalty is focused elsewhere!

Text: Hi, Bit of a long shot... We booked back in March to go to for a family holiday Florida over the summer and we got very bad news yesterday. My mother in law has been diagnosed with stage 3b terminal lung cancer with life expectancy of 3-6mths and told no longer able to fly. We booked on Virgin via Expedia and neither company will even consider exchanging let alone refund for the single ticket. Both insist they would refund but are blaming each other's "rules" none of which deal with their customers as human beings. We have written to both Expedia & Virgin's customer relations as well as their CEOs, tweeted their Twitter accounts, our travel insurance only covers her if she passes away. Any other suggestions? All advice welcome.

Text: I just called to clear the outstanding balance of 6 day trip to NY which cost my friend and I £400 EACH - bargain (or so we thought). When I called a few wks ago to pay of £590 I was informed that the airfare taxes had risen by £20pp. At the time of booking the agent who booked the holiday said it was possible that they would rise once before the o/b was paid off but not by much. I was a bit annoyed that I hadn't been called/emailed and informed of this, and that it was casually mentioned at the time of payment but I accepted it s I was told they need my "ok" before they could deduct the £590 off my card. I asked at least 3 times if the taxes would rise again and was told no repeatedly. All was fine and with the new £20pp tax fee ...my outstanding balance now stood at £64.90 and my friend's was £54.90. I called today (the last day to pay off the booking) to pay the final £119.80 and am told "Oh it's £150 you owe madam and if it's not paid today you will lose the holiday". I've had the worst week imaginable and completely lost my cool as I found it incredibly cheeky that they appeared to have plucked this sum out of the air as I had had my o/b confirmed to me repeatedly during the last phone call 3 weeks ago!! I disputed the o/b and went through the maths with the woman on the phone who couldn't understand what I was saying and was in a bloody call centre in India and who said that she'd escalate my complaint to a manager who'd call tomorrow...cue more ranting from me that today was the last day to pay the o/b and that a phone call tomorrow would be useless if she was saying that I'd lose the holiday if it wasn't paid off today. I asked to be transferred through to the sales team as she was in the customer services team and seemingly in a differennt country! After being put on hold for a while an English sounding guy came on the line, asking what the problem was..at this point I'm in tears as I'm so stressed out and he tells me "You won't lose the holiday as you're talking to me now. You called us, it's fine. Your tickets have been dispatched anyway". He says that the price of the holiday may have gone up and didn't I get any emails from the woman who booked it for me bk in October. I haven't heard from here since the day I bloody booked it!!!!!! I tell him how I was told that the taxes would not be rising again and how I'd budgeted down to the last penny for what I believed I owed. He gave me this agents direct line telling me she'd be in tomorrow 9:00-5:30pm and that she knew more about the booking and would be able to help me. I'm so angry at this shoddy service from Travelocity. You can't go adding money onto peoples outstanding balances without informing them beforehand!!! I lost my job recently so money is tight at the moment and to say I'm still shaking with anger is not an exaggeration! I was in bloody tears to the guy on the phone. I'm so stressed out at the moment. They can't do this again can they??? They'd have the call on tape where I was told in no terms would the taxes be rising again.. I wasn't even told by the lady in India where the additional £30 had come from!!!!!!!! Will be ringing the lady who booked the trip for me first thing tomorrow morning but would appreciate any advice if possible. Many thanks for reading my rant ....*and breathe*

You called us, it's fine. Your tickets have been dispatched anyway". He says that the price of the holiday may have gone up and didn't I get any emails from the woman who booked it for me bk in October. I haven't heard from here since the day I bloody booked it!!!!!! I tell him how I was told that the taxes would not be rising again and how I'd budgeted down to the last penny for what I believed I owed. He gave me this agents direct line telling me she'd be in tomorrow 9:00-5:30pm and that she knew more about the booking and would be able to help me. I'm so angry at this shoddy service from Travelocity. You can't go adding money onto peoples outstanding balances without informing them beforehand!!! I lost my job recently so money is tight at the moment and to say I'm still shaking with anger is not an exaggeration! I was in bloody tears to the guy on the phone. I'm so stressed out at the moment. They can't do this again can they??? They'd have the call on tape where I was told in no terms would the taxes be rising again.. I wasn't even told by the lady in India where the additional £30 had come from!!!!!!!! Will be ringing the lady who booked the trip for me first thing tomorrow morning but would appreciate any advice if possible. Many thanks for reading my rant ....*and breathe*

I was a bit annoyed that I hadn't been called/emailed and informed of this, and that it was casually mentioned at the time of payment but I accepted it s I was told they need my "ok" before they could deduct the £590 off my card. I asked at least 3 times if the taxes would rise again and was told no repeatedly. All was fine and with the new £20pp tax fee ...my outstanding balance now stood at £64.90 and my friend's was £54.90. I called today (the last day to pay off the booking) to pay the final £119.80 and am told "Oh it's £150 you owe madam and if it's not paid today you will lose the holiday". I've had the worst week imaginable and completely lost my cool as I found it incredibly cheeky that they appeared to have plucked this sum out of the air as I had had my o/b confirmed to me repeatedly during the last phone call 3 weeks ago!! I disputed the o/b and went through the maths with the woman on the phone who couldn't understand what I was saying and was in a bloody call centre in India and who said that she'd escalate my complaint to a manager who'd call tomorrow...cue more ranting from me that today was the last day to pay the o/b and that a phone call tomorrow would be useless if she was saying that I'd lose the holiday if it wasn't paid off today. Text: We just returned from a trip to Costa Rica. We were traveling with 4 bags all of which had TSA locks. On our return trip we cleared customs in Miami and re-checked our bags in for our flight home. When we got home all but one on the TSA locks had been removed and not replaced. One of the removed locks we found inside one of the bags. The remaining 3 locks (One case has 2 compartments to lock) are gone. Nothing appears to be missing except the locks, but what good is a TSA lock if they just remove them and throw them away?

Text: I,ve just been looking at a package with Jet2 over xmas/new year to Servigroup Venus where we have stayed many times. I got the price back and had a quick chat with hubby and we decided to go for it and book.Within about 20 mins the price had risen almost £400. I,m so angry, how can they justify this? I had a live web chat with their advisors who more or less said it boils down to supply and demand on flight seats and hotel rooms. I don,t buy that, not in such a short space of time. Well I,m sorry Jet2, you can stick it !!!!! Edited: 9:38 pm, August 04, 2014

It's a tough call to make.

Text: My husband and I went to Hawaii (July 2009) for our Honeymoon and were stranded on the Big Island by this airline. They stopped flying out of Kona days before our flight. They did not contact us and when we got to the airport we found a phone at their counter and were told we were pretty much out of luck. They had not made alternate arrangements, nor could they help. We did not have the credit card we'd used for purchase and were told to call when we got home and they'd refund our money. We specifically asked if we needed to do anything else and were told all we needed was the credit card. Now that we're home they're saying we need to return the paper tickets that the other person was wrong. I find if ludicrous that they strand us and then try to shift responsibility to us for their mistake. We don't have the tickets, so we're supposed to talk to corporate. We've left messages 3 times now and no one is calling back. The only phone number on the website is to reservations and they will send a message, that goes unanswered. I checked Better Business Bureau and they have an F rating and a history of this type of problem and they don't respond to complaints from BBB. Avoid. Avoid. Avoid.

Text: Booked a flight from Prague to Venice through Orbitz on Alitalia. The flight time changed, but Orbitz didn't notify us, I just happened to check the Alitalia website the day before. That wasn't a big drama, but a bit annoying when you book through an agent for some service. The real problem started at the airport, we tried to check in but the airline had no record of our booking even though Orbitz had issued us paper tickets showing apparent valid ticket numbers. I tried to call Orbitz at the airport but by the time I finally got to speak to someone and have them understand that a) I was at the airport trying to check in b) No, i didn't want to cancel my booking and c) I am Australian, so my zip code has only 4 digits, we were forced to purchase new tickets at the airport to be able to board at a cost of around $250 before check-in close. Since the flight, I have tried to contact Alitalia about the issue, with no response whatsoever and Orbitz by email, who just say to call. When I call, I'm repeatedly put on hold (paying international call rates) and was told on the last call that "Orbitz will not refund the tickets as the airline re-accommodated us on a later flight." They do not read my emails or listen to what I have to say (ie. we only got on the later flight after we purchased new tickets), just keep repeating the line that the airline put on a later flight. I don't want a refund for the original tickets, I want a refund for the more expensive tickets that we had to purchase at the airport! Any ideas of what else I can do? I'm sure we have some rights under the Montreal Convention but it's hard to make any claims when you get no response from the airline or incoherent, useless responses from the agent!

The flight time changed, but Orbitz didn't notify us, I just happened to check the Alitalia website the day before.[ That wasn't a big drama, but a bit annoying when you book through an agent for some service. The real problem started at the airport, we tried to check in but the airline had no record of our booking even though Orbitz had issued us paper tickets showing apparent valid ticket numbers. I tried to call Orbitz at the airport but by the time I finally got to speak to someone and have them understand that a) I was at the airport trying to check in b) No, i didn't want to cancel my booking and c) I am Australian, so my zip code has only 4 digits, ]we were forced to purchase new tickets at the airport to be able to board at a cost of around $250 before check-in close.[ Since the flight, I have tried to contact Alitalia about the issue, with no response whatsoever and Orbitz by email, who just say to call. When I call, I'm repeatedly put on hold (paying international call rates) and was told on the last call that "Orbitz will not refund the tickets as the airline re-accommodated us on a later flight." They do not read my emails or listen to what I have to say (ie. we only got on the later flight after we purchased new tickets), just keep repeating the line that the airline put on a later flight.] I don't want a refund for the original tickets, I want a refund for the more expensive tickets that we had to purchase at the airport! Any ideas of what else I can do?[ I'm sure we have some rights under the Montreal Convention but it's hard to make any claims when you get no response from the airline or incoherent, useless responses from the agent!]
Annotator B Text: Booked a flight from Prague to Venice through Orbitz on Alitalia. [The flight time changed, but Orbitz didn't notify us, I just happened to check the Alitalia website the day before. That wasn't a big drama, but a bit annoying when you book through an agent for some service. The real problem started at the airport, we tried to check in but the airline had no record of our booking even though Orbitz had issued us paper tickets showing apparent valid ticket numbers. I tried to call Orbitz at the airport but by the time I finally got to speak to someone and have them understand that a) I was at the airport trying to check in b) No, i didn't want to cancel my booking and c) I am Australian, so my zip code has only 4 digits, we were forced to purchase new tickets at the airport to be able to board at a cost of around $250 before check-in close. Since the flight, I have tried to contact Alitalia about the issue, with no response whatsoever and Orbitz by email, who just say to call. When I call, I'm repeatedly put on hold (paying international call rates) and was told on the last call that "Orbitz will not refund the tickets as the airline re-accommodated us on a later flight." They do not read my emails or listen to what I have to say (ie. we only got on the later flight after we purchased new tickets), just keep repeating the line that the airline put on a later flight.] I don't want a refund for the original tickets, I want a refund for the more expensive tickets that we had to purchase at the airport! Any ideas of what else I can do? [I'm sure we have some rights under the Montreal Convention but it's hard to make any claims when you get no response from the airline or incoherent, useless responses from the agent!]

Text: They hide the fact that some tickets they sell do not carry airmiles with them. This cost me a business class upgrade on my next flight. I contacted them they deny it, I went through the process again and kept recods of the booking process and id does not warn you. EVA say they tell Ebookers that they have to warn customers, they don't if they are then it is hidden and I can't find it. In essence they are conning people so be warned. The response from Ebookers and EVA was totally poor. I am now flying Emirates again and will never use Ebookers again. They are not ABTA bonded either I found out as a result of this so again BE WARNED. Try West East Travel instead, lovely very helpful and cheaper. -----.

Text: Over the years Qantas has moved out of many regional routes and replaced their Qantas flights with Jetstar. I travel a lot to/from Sydney and use Jetstar 6+ times a month which of course always take off and land at T2 in Sydney. So, Qantas in its wisdom (or a sign of the economic times) has closed the Qantas Club Lounge at T2. A lot of us pay $450+ per year for a Qantas Club membership - if you cant fly Qantas (because they now fly Jetstar) the lounge in T2 was well worth it. Qantas say "oh, just use the lounge in T3" - well, easier said than done - you have to go through security at T3 to get to the Qantas lounge (ever done that at 7am in the morning), then leave T3 and go through security again at T2. Qantas say they haven't had very many complaints on this closure (have you ever tried to navigate the Qantas web site to find a complaint form?). I did then was sent an invite to join the American Express® Qantas Corporate Card program - what? Maybe if 1,000 people decide not to renew their Qantas Club membership then the loss of $450,000 might create a rethink in the halls of power and they will reopen a (smaller) T2 Qantas lounge. Yeah, maybe not. In any event if you agree and think this is a bad decision please post to this forum topic. Ill be happy to let Qantas know.

Text: At least twice a year I visit friends in Sacramento, flying from the UK. My preferred route is Leeds- AMS- then either Portland or Seattle with a Delta on an A330-300 which I always enjoy in economy class. A very late booking, and looking for the cheapest flight, means that next week I fly KLM to LAX on a 747 which I did last summer. Inbound though, from Minneapolis to AMS it is a Delta 767-400ER. I was just idly wondering if it is much different to the A330 which I normally fly on and which has a great choice of films....I normally watch more films on a flight than I do the rest of the year at home! Not really important, but grateful for any comparisons from any aircraft savvy people!
