Text: Dear Readers I recently (June and July2010) travelled to Europe from Australia with my wife and 3 children aged 16,11 and 9. We visited France, Greece and England. I booked and paid for 3 flights with Easy Jet prior to our departure. The first two flights were uneventful. However our last flight from Athens to London ended up blowing my holiday budget out of the water. We were booked on an Olympic Air flight out of Paros in the Greek Islands a flight that is 20 minutes in length and was scheduled to depart at 16.05pm. Our Easy Jet Connection was due to depart at 19.00 and check in closed at 18.20. Due to the late incoming plane to Paros we did not arrive in at Athens airport until 17.55pm and we were promptly transferred to the terminal by an awaiting bus and were in the terminal at 18.00. I advised my wife and children to go and retrieve the bags and I raced up to the Easy Jet counter to commence check in. By the time I got to the counter it was 18.18pm on my watch and on the clocks in the terminal but there were no Easy Jet staff at the check in at all. The next day there was an Air Traffic Controllers strike that had been scheduled and we had non-refundable accommodation and other paid activities in London. I went looking for the Easy Jet representative in the Terminal who advised that as it was at that stage, 18.21pm by her watch the flight had closed, there were no staff available and there was nothing she could do other than advise us that due to industrial action and bookings we would not be likely to get paid seats with Easy Jet for 3 days. Faced with this I looked for flights departing to London that night and found a British Airways flight due to depart at 19.10. I was advised by a BA representative that she may be able to get 5 seats but would not know until 18.40. She managed to get 5 economy seats for which I was charged in excess of EURO2500 or Australian $3557.00. I spoke to BA the next day in London and a staff member told me that I was charged adult fares for the two children under 12 and that I should be entitled to a 25% refund. The battle to do this is still going on with the BA refunds section and the initial response that I received when the matter was referred to BA customer relations was that BA only have 2 classes of economy seats adult and infant ie 2 and under. There website would suggest otherwise. I have written to Easy Jet and am awaiting a response and will detail it in this forum when it is to hand. I think the moral of this story is that allow the widest possible berth between connection if travelling on a discount carrier. Do not accept the check in closure time will be adhered to by staff of a budget carrier and make sure that you have travel insurance that covers the scenario of a missed connection, as many policies in this regard will only give you a limited amount in very limited circumstances. I will keep you all posted. ------- Sydney

Text: We returned Saturday evening from London via British Airway. Part of our bucket list (things we want to experience before we "kick the bucket") was to fly British Airways First Class and/or Business Class. I hope anyone with a love of travel and have traveled for many years squeezed into "the back", can have this experience!. All you need to do is save up those Frequent Flyer miles for years and years of loyally flying the Star Alliance airlines in the narrow, crowded seats and keeping a sense of humor knowing you are doing your favorite thing, traveling to far away countries. We will probably never again be able to afford to travel this way, certainly not enough time to collect miles nor save enough money....BUT , the memory of this experience on British Airways will last until the end of our days. In past years when I traveled domestically first class for business with my employer paying the fare , it was NOTHING like this. Airlines, and service have come a long way, Never could I imagine this experience. I remember boarding in the back, under the tail, and walking up the aisle, and using a pillow for a tray....Ahhh, and now sleeping pods, pajamas, slippers, 5 star meals, top shelf spirits and the most polite incredible flight attendants, obviously the creme de la creme.. Now, we two "mature" people celebrating our 50th anniversary, know what goes on behind the curtain!. I hope all you lovers of travel can share the experience one day.

Text: Bad publicity=results Great news! Air Canada has taken back some of the rouge flights down to Barbados. Our flight is on Feb 1st and we have gone from a 319 to a 767 and are now on a 77L. No more rouge!! at least not on the YYZ-BGI route (for some flights) I haven't done a lot of checking but I noticed equipment changes from early Dec. to end of Feb. for now. If you have a flight in that time period, check your seats. We haven't been notified yet but I did see that our seats are not blocked out and I can't change seats online. Guess that's a call to Air Canada. To those of you who helped us get Air Canada's attention by expressing our displeasure through CBC, CTA and the Competition Bureau as well as here and Flyertalk ... Thank you!

Text: As a regular traveller, I am used to the usual airport customs/immigration lines at airports. That is why I was so glad to hear Pres Obama himself proclaiming the wonderful advances in passenger processing at DFW for US Citz plus anyone travelling with ESTA. Therefore I was horrified by the 3hrs line up yesterday at DFW, making hundreds miss their connections (I had booked a 4hr connection - so we made it). The reason for the lines? 3 booths out of 28 were open. 1hr later they opened 16 more. Yes, there were 6 international flights landing within 20 mintues of each other, but in this day and age they must surely be fully aware of the number of passengers on each flight, their nationalities and their exact arrival time - many hours in advance. And to think we travelled via DFW in order to avoid LAX - not next time we wont Rant over !

Text: Some of you may remember my post from last year: tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowTopic-g1-i10702-k64972… The thread appears to have been frozen, however I resurrect it now to give you an update ... Until last week I hadn't flown from CWL since the incident in the previous thread, but last Monday once again my contact lens solution was selected at for testing ... Once again, the staff were polite and professional - but this time I was prepared! My regular "explosive" solution was in my checked luggage, and in my hand luggage I was just carrying a 100ml bottle of solution that Specsavers said shouldn't test positive - and they were right. It passed the swab test and I was allowed to take it with me. In all the years I've been travelling I have never had contact lens solution tested at any other airport (apart from once in Bilbao, when they suspected it was something totally different - but that's another story ...), but maybe this will help anyone travelling through Cardiff with contact lens solution in their hand luggage - they seem to be on the lookout for it (I was assured I was simply chosen at random, though I'm sure I spotted a look of glee in the security staff eyes when they saw the bottle going through the X-ray machine ...). For clarification, the solution that tested positive was Specsavers' Easyvision Allpurpose solution; the "safe" solution is the Easyvision Multipurpose. If anyone needs a 100ml bottle, they have a stock in Specsavers in Queen Street Cardiff ;-)

Text: Recently, I was on a full flight. Various nationalities were represented, and an American couple was giving the flight attendant a really hard time about nearby passengers "who smelled bad". They had angled their air vents toward said passengers, thus in turn causing them to complain. Despite American's culture of bathing, deodorant and perfumes, I once read that North Americans smell bad to Asians. Who knew? Manners, odors, demeanors, all are culturally different and possible offenses. So I learned something new. Pack a small TSA approved tin of Vicks vapor rub, to have handy in the event of odoriferous confines. In the end, we are all responsible for our own comfort.

Text: I just wanted to post this in case anyone else has flight anxiety. I get very nervous on flights, and at one time, broke into full blown tears becuase I thought the plane was going down in turbulence! I went to my doctor, and she just wrote me a script for Ativan. I wanted to try to kick this fear DRUG FREE. On my Ipod, I downloaded an App - Virgin Atlantic Fear of Flying. It was $4.99 and worth every penny. It has videos of a captain talking about different sounds, movements, and things to expect. It has demos on how planes operate, land, take off, etc as well. It also has those relaxation tracks on it. (a guy speaking sllllooowly and telling you everything is going to be fiiiinnne.) I listened to it on my last flight the whole way, and the 2 weeks leading up to it. By no means do I love flying now, but I can tolerate it, and I'm not anxious and fearful. I encourage anyone with the same feelings that I did to check it out!

Text: This is what happening just now and though I would share this with you..... After a terrible frustrating week of delays, canceled flights etc, etc, traveling all over the UK and Ireland, a friend of mine is currently sitting on yet another runway. (last one was Manchester two days ago) All was well the flight was due to take off on time great everyone happy, all passengers on the plane, first flight this week to do so for my friend, but wait... Sitting waiting, waiting, waiting, for almost an hour on the plane, when Ryanair announced there would be a delay..............as they did not have a captain on board, so said capitano has been found but now its snowing and they have lost their slot and are at the end of the q. Now I know the Captain may of been stuck in snow, unable to get in but.....just feel so sorry for travellers who have have a awful time travelling this week... Gota love em!

Text: Just did an online check in for my trip to Prague in a few weeks time with Jet2. Edinburgh to Prague,didn't pay extra for seat and took the allocated seats for both outbound an inbound flights. both seat are 2C,which is an ailse seat near the door,so I can be last on and first off, couldn't have asked for better or even paid for it. travelling solo and hand luggage only so i am a happy chappy. I have noticed now that on their boarding pass they have a warning about hand luggage clearly stating the size and weight limits and how much they will charge if it is too big or too heavy,good idea in my opinion.

Text: We used Orbitz for a recent flight to Mexico. We had nothing but problems from the start. It took 3 phone calls and a request for a supervisor before the problem was solved to get us to our destination. On the return flight, we arrived at the airport and we were told we were on standby! We had reservations for 3 months!!! We were not able to get on a flight and ended up renting a car to get home while others who were on the "overbooked" list, were offered $500 trip voucher and a hotel room. Needless to say, we will never use or recommend Orbitz again. Jane

Text: Are travellers aware that in booking a package with Expedia that, in the case of Air France, luggage charges will be added to the fare at the check in desk, and you will be asked for immediate payment before being allowed to board? We recently returned from a trip to Florence, having booked a hotel and flights deal. On arriving at the desk, we were charged in excess of an extra £100 'baggage charges'. Of course, Expedia will no doubt point out that they do say (in quite small print) that 'the airline may make extra charges'. Such a pity that these nasty little surprises await us to add to the already stressful event that air travel has become, driven by the grubby and petty greed of formerly honourable companies. Read everything, no matter how small the print - NEVER trust a travel firm, 'tourist' has for some time meant 'sucker'. PM

Text: Hi everyone, A quick question - we have booked through BA to travel to Bali, via Changi. We're flying British Airways from LHR to Singapore, but our connecting flight is on Jetstar, and as we have quite a long time between flights in Changi (12 hours), we would like to make use of the transit hotel. However, as we will not be checked in from London straight through to Bali, we will have to reclaim our bags from the BA flight and then check in to the Jetstar one. As far as I can tell, both airlines use Terminal 1. My question is: will we be classed as transit passengers and therefore be able to use the transit hotel? My concern is that we will have to clear immigration in order to collect our bags, but then find that we are stuck landside and unable to use the hotel because check-in for our Jetstar flight to Bali doesn't open until several hours after our flight from London arrives. If anyone could put my mind at rest I'd be most grateful - thank you!

Text: So my husband recently made MM Gold with American. Totally out of the blue (but in full disclosure, he was Gold with AA for the last many years he worked, so we are no strangers to the front yard). But Speedbird recently linked me to an AA wikie, which linked to the Flyertalk forum, where I read about XPlats not getting upgraded on certain routes. Plus we were on a direct which was only going to be 5 stickers instead of the usual 7 for that connecting routing...so we figured we had no chance. Checking the website the night before (well within our 24 hr. window...still nothing). But when we got to the airport the next day and I was at the kiosk, the first thing that caught my eye was "TWO MEALS" - yeah baby, we've hit the big time, LOL. Yes, it was only on a direct MD-80 = but it was still cool. Loved the nuts, the free food, the chocolate chip cookies. Won't get anymore free stickers until we fly 10,000 (which will definitely happen this year), but yeah, it was sure nice. I'm almost happy I figured we had no chance because it was such a nice surprise.

Text: I booked a flight with Travelbag online website, and entered full payment details, only to receive an email response that "Your reservation arrangements are now being finalised and you will be contacted by a consultant, either by email or by telephone, within the next 72 hours to confirm your arrangements.". Ridiculous to wait for a flight booking for 3 days, prices change every day, its either confirmed or you book somewhere else. There is nothing in the booking process that suggests this will be the case, though on later inspection there is something embedded in the T&Cs. I emailed and also tried to call the support line to find they are only open 11am to 5pm. Called the next morning and got bumped to a voicemail. Still waiting for an email or call back for a conformation or refund. This is bad behavior, suggest *** AVOID *** booking flights with Traavelbag online.

Text: We flew Easy Jet a week before Christmas from Luton to Faro, I had two small suitcases one of 7 kilos and one of 10 kilos, check in at Luton was fast and friendly, however on the return journey at check-in at Faro airport, they refused my identical pieces/weight and wanted to charge me for the second item, resulting in my having to throw away expensive cosmetics and a bottle of wine and to carry as hand baggage. Have written by recorded letter to Easy Jet head office, no reply after a month, does anyone have any suggestions for me, I am still angry with Easy Jet, many thanks Stuart W

Text: At the risk of being hung drawn & quartered for saying this, I have to say, after our first flight with RA, we were impressed. Flew with RA to Malaga 3 wks ago, no luggage issues, very clean aircraft, comfy seats, good leg room & friendly FAs. Yes we read & re-read the T & Cs just in case & even took our own luggage scales ready for battle but no problems whatsoever. Return flight from Barcelona with BMI Baby a couple of days ago (also our first trip with them)on a less than clean, rather rickety plane not as impressive. Sorry to praise RA but I thought, in the interests of fairness I had to praise where praise due.

Text: Hi there I booked a holiday through Thomascook.com for my wife and I to fly to Kenya in October. This was scheduled to be flying with Monarch Airlines. When I received my confirmation - I noticed I was charged £20.00 per person for an extra 5kg of baggage - taking my total UP TO 20kg!!! Is that all????? Having looked at the Monarch Airlines website - all passengers flying to Mombasa are allowed a baggage allowance of 35kg PER PASSENGER. If you booked Premium Class this went up to 45kg PER PASSENGER!! I've been in touch with them and they refuse to budge! I've since cancelled my holiday with them and booked through Cosmos and got exactly the deal I was after..... 3 weeks in Kenya to look forward to, and 45kg of luggage each. This will enable us to take extra clothing to distribute among the local population as we did in 2005. Dave Hill

Text: My wife and I merged our North West World Perks miles with our Delta Sky Miles accounts. Afterwards, we found out that even if you have a recent flight with NW and your miles would not expire for quite a while, the Delta expiration date does not get changed. We are now facing a very short time to use our Delta Sky Miles or we loose them. If we had known that, we would not have merged them. Just another sad case of loosing our favorite airline in a merger. We lost TWA, which for us was a great airline until American destroyed it in the merger. We are expecting to loose a lot with the Delta takeover of North West.

Text: My son was going to Mexico for 6 months travelling with Delta via Atlanta. He got an ESTA which is supposed to be valid for 2 years and for stays of up to 90 days, IN THE US. He went to the airport and checked in, then he was told by DELTA staff he couldn't fly because he was going to be in Mexico for more than 90 days; and Delta were treating Mexico as a US State so he needed a US Visa - even though he was not entering the US. Is it me?

Text: Does anyone think there will be a back lash against Ryan air soon? Their latest ploy of charging for baggage to be put in the hold, when the current hand baggage legislation size rules are very tight, is a bit of a cheek. Then you get the CEO pretty much admitting that he doesn't want passengers sleeping on his planes so he is able to get his staff to seel them as much duty free/food/scratchcards as possible. With BA and other better quality European airliners reducing their prices, I wonder if the middle class who have embraced Ryan Air, will start being happy to pay a few quid more and fly with a bit more sophistication.

Text: We flew to Phoenix from Toronto last week. This was bar none the worst flight I have ever taken. It was tighter than any Air Transat that I've flown. The seats are so close together that even I was uncomfortable at 5 feet tall. My husband is over 6 feet and he was miserable. I fortunately was in the aisle seat but the couple occupying the middle and window had a 2 year old on their lap. I felt very sorry for them. The wife couldn't even get her purse out from under the seat until we all stood up. I took out my tape measure and measured the distance from the front edge of my seat to the seat in front. It was 7 inches!! Up until now I have opted for Air Canada when travelling south but no more! There is also no TV on Rouge so you better have an IPad or be prepared to pay $10 to rent one.

Text: Sorry to keep banging on about Ryanair, but now that I've started............ I was just curious, has anyone noticed that when you price a flight on Ryanair for one person, then go back and price it for more than one person the price goes up (per person)? Thought I was going mad the first time it happened, but it's happened every time since. For instance flight to Faro from Stn on 25 May 0.01p for one person. Change it to 4 persons and it's £19.99 pp! How's that fair?

Text: We are flying to Orlando in 2 weeks for our last full family holiday as our eldest is oing to NZ in October to live. As it was special we paid extra to go with Thomson, as it was adverised as a Dreamliner route and then decided to go Premium to make it more special. We got an email today from Thomson telling us that they have changed the plane back to one that doesn't have any premium seats, I presume this is the 767. I imagine this has happened before so has anyone had any experience with Thomson on getting a decent explanation why? We have been refunded the money for the one way but it's more to do with spooling my daughters dream holiday. My youngest is 8, is a big aircraft fanatic and is really upset and is now experiencing a negative before we have even set off. It may sound petty but we only booked with Thomson because of the Dreamliner and Virgin was cheaper.

Text: Hi All, Me and my fiance are getting married next month in Thailand, and are travelling with Emirates via Dubai. I wish to take a small amount of my Fathers ashes with me, to scatter prior the the ceremony so a part of him is there with us on our special day, and was wondering if there are any restrictions, or specific protocol regarding this? I am more than happy to put a small amount of his ashes in a suitable spill proof container, and pack them in my hold luggage, so was wondering if it is necessary to inform the airline, and bring all of the documentation (death certificate etc) as it will only be a very small amount in a tiny box, packed in my suitcase. Text: Dear Air France and fellow passengers, I write here today to explain to anyone considering flying with Air France to reconsider. The service I have received by them in the last 24h has been absolutely appalling. After a cancelled flight I was made to wait for almost 4 hours to be attended, at which time any options for rebooking has already left or were full. Hence my morning meeting on 23/11 will be missed, and my prepaid car rental at MIA is lost. I reschedule meetings for 4pm on 23/11 assuming a 12:25 landing. After waking up at 5am I arrive at the airport to find that my 8:30am flight had become a 10:20am flight (no email or courtesy call from AF). So another meeting to reschedule last minute and perhaps lost business. Additionally the upgrade to premium economy I was promised.....no longer the case today! This is the absolute worst treatment by an airline I have ever received and I intent to pursue my rights as a passenger according to EC261/2004 or other applicable regulations to ensure my losses and expenses are reimbursed. Yours sincerely, Bob Vandedrink

Text: We're travelling on a family holiday to the US in three weeks and I have only just realised that as someone born in the US I must enter on a valid US passport. (last time 6 years ago, I was advised to take both but travel on my UK one and was never asked for my US one) I've submitted an application for renewal of my very lapsed US passport today but it's clear that there is very little chance of it arriving in time. Has anyone had any experience of this situation and am I likely to be able to get an emergency passport to travel? The Embassy can't tell me this and have advised I wait until 3 days before travel before even contacting their emergency line. I'm despairing and we're all frantic!

Text: United is changing the rules about Premier. NO Economy Plus at reservation... only on day of departure. So that means they are trying to sell the seats to one time fliers instead of reserving for those who have almost 50k miles. Also, taking away one bag at check-in. But those who pay for Explorer card get two free bags if they only fly 500 miles a year. NOT FAIR. What can we do?

Text: Always one to reduce costs, Ryanair are implementing cost saving initiatives. With the rising cost of fuel the airline has found ways of reducing the fuel bill by reducing the weight it carries on its flights. They will be shrinking the size of its in-flight magazines from A4 to A5 size, carrying less ice on flights and believe it or not, "encouraging" staff to watch their weight - with the motivation of appearing in the annual Ryanair calendar! But Ryanair are only following in the foot steps of other airlines ... In the 1980's, American Airlines claimed that they saved $40,000 by taking out one olive from every salad in first class and more recently, Japanese airline All Nippon Airways started asking passengers to go to the toilet before boarding in a bid to reduce carbon emissions! Without fuel you cannot fly, but I think that's taking things a step too far !

I could select the timings by using a translator plug-in in the browser as some websites are not in English language. Text: I am flying from Luton to Dalaman (Turkey) next week with Monarch and am wondering whether or not to bother with online check-in. We already have allocated seats, so as far as I can see the only extra thing that online check-in offers is that you don't have to have your boarding pass printed at the check-in desk. Things that are putting me off are: (1) I've noticed over the past couple of years that because now most people are checking in online, the queues for the online check-in desks are often actually longer than the queues for people who haven't checked in online (2) Last year we had a 12 hour flight delay - the original plane had a problem and the airline then split passengers into two groups and people who had NOT checked in online were flown out on a much earlier plane than those who had checked in online - goodness knows why.

Not sure if I can have AA (as they issued the tickets) in DFW send my luggage directly to RGN? One element is that Dragon Air is a Cathay affiliate and they are all Oneworld. Text: BA has won their case in the High Court attacking the balloting process. There will need to be a re-vote, which will take at least 4 weeks, so the Christmas flights are back on. It is not clear what the cabin service will be like....but there is some evidence that some union members were taken by surprise that their vote for "industrial action" turned into a 12 days over-Christmas strike.

Text: my wife and I were returning from Manchester, UK to D.C., then on to Louisville, KY. a *HUGE* storm brought down powerlines on the tracks of the UK train that was to get us to Manchester airport. We had to wind up taking a taxi, but half way there it was obvious that we would no make our flight. From the cab, I cell-phoned the only number I had - a toll-free US number. AUnited agent finally came on the line and I expalined the situ to her. Long time on hold.... Then she came back. Not only did the lady on the phone get us rescheduled on the same two flights on the following day, but there was *NO* "change fee" charged to us for making the changes! I was astounded! It reminded me of the "old days" when it was a snap to make last-minute flight changes without penalties. Anyway, I want to thank United for getting us back safe & sound and let them know that they will be at the top of our list for carriers when we book our next overseas flights!

Text: I would not recommend this airline to anyone. On a recent trip October 2014, on the way from Madrid to Casablanca, all five of our group didn't get their bag in Casablanca. The staff were very rude and unhelpful. My friends were expected to make there way out to the airport at their own expense to collect their bags! Also No help was offered with expenses during the 3 days they were without their bags. To make matters even more upsetting, on the way back to Madrid they left mine and my wife's bags in Casablanca also. I recommend you google reviews/complaints about this airline before you plan your blissful holiday!

Text: Think wait-times at U.S. airports are maddening? If so, then consider this dramatically written story from the Hindustan Times of New Delhi, where international passengers are being advised to arrive four hours before their flights. The paper says "passengers trying to board flights at (New Delhi's) Indira Gandhi International Airport have fainted or have had epileptic fits due to the claustrophobic conditions prompted by construction work that has led to the closure of large chunks of areas, airlines operating from the airport have said. The airport — in the midst of a massive facelift — has shrunk considerably, leading to serpentine queues that regularly delay flights. People have missed their flights as they spend hours first battling a gut-crushing rush at the airport's entrance and then the immigration counters during the peak travel season." Construction is scheduled to end in April.

Text: Just to set the scene... I have a fairly tall husband who likes to complain on long flights when his legs are hurting him. In the past we have been lucky in getting the seat next to the exits with the extra legroom on scheduled flights on a few occasions. I recall getting these seats when we asked politely at the check in desk. Ideally, we would love to get these seats when we travel to Bangkok (economy) - although I know there is no guarantee and after reading posts they can be allocated to passengers with 'elite' status etc I believe these seats are only assigned by the airport check in staff on the day (or at least this is what I thought I read on the Emirates website). We have selected the next best seats for us through the online booking manager system. My question is therefore this - if we check in online, will this mean we automatically won't be able to get the seats with the extra legroom?

Text: This isn't a question, but more of a personal testimony of a good flight from a company with a bad reputation. This was my first flight, so I did a lot of research. We flew from LBE to Myrtle Beach the first week of May with Spirit. This is a basic airline. The rules are clear. Our flight was on time, we arrived early, and had no problems. LBE is a small airport and very easy to navigate. Leaving MYR, several women in line behind me had suitcases way over the 40lb posted limit, had several bags and purses, and were mad about having to pay. Pack smart, weigh your luggage, and buy the Big Front Seat if you can. It is well worth the extra money - especially if 2 people are going to fly together.

Text: Our son lives in Atlanta and from time to time we get our grandchildren to come visit us in Florida. They have been flying in and out of Orlando on Air Tran. Now this is NOT a rant post against Air Tran but I am going to start flying them on Delta out of Melbourne. Reason being that the last two times we went to Orlando the service was so slooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooow that they missed the booked flight. Their luggage made it A ok but it took so long to get me a gate pass after they were checked in that we did not get to the gate in time. The problem seems to be two fold. First of all there are NOT enough agents to handle the load. Second is that you must stand in a line that is at the very end of the ticketing area and do not have a dedicated agent to deal with. So you must wait until another line is empty or another agent comes from the "back" to assist you. Maybe it is just Orlando and not Air Tran but I have never had any of those problems flying from Melbourne. Additionaly the security at Orlando is poorly organized and the TSA agents are in no hurry to get you to the airside on time. That is NOT the case in Melbourne as they are expediant and professional at all times.

Text: I appreciate that there are still alot of stranded people out there and I hope you all get home soon. but here was our story. I thought it best to wait 'till we all got home so we can give hopefully a balanced perspective of events. We were due to fly home on 15th April, when it all first happened from Atlanta. We were about 250 miles from the airport, just waking up in our hotel room when we heard the news on CNN, and obviously devastated. It was more the "not knowing" than anything else. The website (BA) told us not to go to the airport, and it was about 2.5 hours to speak to someone on the phone. We had to go and return the rental car anyway at ATL so had some hours to calm down and think a bit, rather than turn up to check in totally unaware and panic. The news in the U.S on this was fairly low key at the time from what we saw, and we got more information by logging on to UK news websites, it really felt like doom and gloom from what the media were saying. On our arrival at check in, we handed in my pre printed boarding passes to the BA check in staff, and decided just to book ourselves on the next available flight out, which was 6 days later. Again feeling devastated by the wait and potential additional expense that wasn't budgeted for (or so we thought). The kids were upset, the wife too, however "keep calm" I said to myself, trying to hold it all together ,as there is nothing you can do. BA check in staff were truely exceptional, along with ATL dispatchers for the flight (BA226 ATL-LHR on 15th Apr '10). Although they could not doing anything about the flight, their service went beyond the call of duty in terms of help, advice, and being put up in a hotel nearby with all meals paid for. BA, the hotel staff, ATL staff, and the British Consulate in downtown all worked together for the benefit of the passengers. All of them worked 110% to help us, and it will never be forgotten. I was aware of the other horror stories from other airlines just "dumping" their passengers with little more than $7 per day to survive on. We remember a group of 4/5 parent helpers looking after 20 or so kids who were representing the UK in a robotic tournament in Atlanta flying on an American airline who had to start paying out of their own pockets. I hope you got back safely if you're reading this. We also rememberd at the consulate, another passenger "dumped" by another European airline, with no one to talk to, speak to, or given any advice until the Consulate stepped in. There are hundreds more I know, and we are lucky to be what I think are the fortunate few who flew on BA. I'm not one to hype up BA, as I had some reservations on flying with them, but after this experience, and if I ever decide to fly again then there will only be 1 airline to choose from. I hope everyone can receive some form of recompense. Up to then my faith in British society had been strained to say the least, but this experience is something I'll never forget, that yes there are people out there who care and want to make a difference. I hope everyone out there still gets home safely and quickly.

Text: Hi, As information for any US passport holder or future applicant. New passport fees will become effective from 13 July 2010 onward. This is for all applications lodged *on or after* this date. Remember if you use a passport acceptance office (like a US post office) or one of the regional Department of State Passport Offices, it's the date on which you actually file or submit your application that will determine the fee matrix. If you are eligible to, and use regular US Mail for submission, it's the post mark date that will govern. Note that the one of the biggest increases (expressed as percentage) is in the additional page insert fee, which goes from *free* to $82 per insert added. Here's the entire new fee matrix from the DoS' Passport Services page: travel.state.gov/passport/fees/fees_5079.html If your passport is going to expire soon, will have less than 6 months validity, or you need to add extra pages, this would be an *excellent* time to do so, before the new fee matrix becomes applicable. Travel Safe,

Text: Hi. Two weeks ago we had an email from Silkair telling us they were moving our return flight from Langkawi to Singapore back a day from 26th February 2015 to the 27th February 2015. This was a disaster for me because on the 26th I am meeting up with my sister who lives in Sydney, before she flies back on the 27th. I haven't seen her since 2008. I informed Silkair of the problem and they asked if I wanted a refund. I immediately said yes and then rebooked with Air Asia to land in Singapore on the 27th. But then Silkair said they could re-route me via KL on the 27th, so I told them I had already booked the other tickets and asked for a refund. They then sent an email asking if I wanted to cancel the flights, so I said yes, and outlined the problem again. For the last few days I've heard nothing. Do you think I'll get my money back? It was their decision to change the dates of the flights.

Text: What a diabolical service AA provide. We had never used them before & got to LAX for a flight to Las Vegas only to find out it had been cancelled. Even though mobile phone number was provided when booking made, I received no phone call or SMS. We were not even trandferred or wait listed on the following flight (even though I hold a gold card (emerald) for a partner airline). Told us we were booked on a flight 6 hours later which would have meant we would have missed our pre-booked trips in Vegas. After inquiring about car hire & how long it would take to drive - we were informed that we'd get there before the one were not wait listed on would have even taken off !!! After a bit more complaining the manager came out & offered t omove us across to United Airlins. I bet that hurt :-) Return flight to Hawaii was not much better either, but we'll save that for another time. Spoke to Rolf Saxon at Las Vegas airport who wasflying on our flight to San Fran (on Virgin America) & even he said he would NOT fly with AA, & being an actor he is flying around alll the time !!!

Text: My mother (who has balance issues and walks with a cane) plans to fly alone to visit relatives out of state. I know I can arrange for a wheelchair at the airport so that she won't have to walk the long distance through the terminal to the gate. My problem is that I would like to accompany her to the gate and wait with her for her flight, so that if she needs to use the bathroom (which is a very frequent need for her) while waiting, I can help her get to the restroom safely. I believe, however, that since 9/11 only ticketed passengers are allowed to go through security to the gate. Does anyone know if there are any exceptions made to this rule, and if so how to arrange this? The airport that she will be flying out of is LaGuardia in NYC. Thank you for your help.

Text: After a few tense days of waiting for an outcome, USAirways International Customer Service has come through with shining colors. I accidently entered my last name on my mother's reservation to Italy and the mistake was not caught immediately. After reporting the problem via their website, I searched the internet to find all kinds of horrible results to similar situations including having to repurchase the ticket (without refund) at the current going rate. The current rate is now $500 more than it was a week ago! I would like to thank Shirley from International Reservations for her diligent persistence in helping me to correct a name error. Without her help, I would still be worrying whether TSA would allow my mother to fly with the ticket on which I incorrectly entered my last name instead of hers. Shirley was great and fixed the problem with no issue. She was polite during the entire transaction and gave me updates along the way so I would feel comfortable on hold. Thanks again for her help. Also, thank you to Dan from Internet Support for starting the correction process.

Text: My daughter recently booked a flight from London Heathrow to Ottawa via Washington. On arrival at the airport she was told she needed an Esta form before she could book in. As she was only in transit at Washington airport and not leaving the terminal she was not aware she needed one. Please be aware that you will not be allowed to travel without one. She did eventually obtain an Esta number from the internet site and just managed to catch he flight but it was very stressful and time consuming. She had a connecting flight from Washington to Ottawa with a two hour time span. Please be aware this is not enough time to negotiate customs and immigration and get to your next boarding gate if you are travelling through Dulles airport. Luckily the Wasington to Ottawa flight was delayed or she would have had to spend the night in the airport. They also lost her luggage!!! Moral of this story is pay the extra for a direct flight!

Text: Some airlines systems are not compatible with others, eg aer lingus/jetblue. This causes problems with online check in and managing your booking. In my case, I cannot check online, or check for changes, and will have to turn up at the airport extra early to get the seats I want. It also meant calling both airlines when I wanted to make a change to my itinerary and is just an all round pain. However, I didn't realize that I could check both airlines for this flight until after I had booked. It may be that I could have got my flight cheaper on one if they had not sold out their allocation of lowest fare seats. Feel free to add any other tips. I am not a frequent flier with major airlines, but perhaps there is an issue with air miles etc?

Text: Recently had a brilliant short visit to Saigon. Absolutely loved Vietnam. However, on arrival home, locks on 2 pieces of luggage were (quite obviously) intentionally broken. Plus everything inside was moved around. There were 6 bags altogether but only 2 were broken into. I figured it probably happened at Saigon as we checked in 2 hrs earlier but when we got home, all the luggage was out immediately. We haven't yet noticed anything missing. I made a mistake of leaving few one dollar notes in there which definitely was a temptation. Dont put anything that can be 'tempting' in your check in luggage even if it doesnt cost much eg. costume jewellery/ accesories. Locks dont always keep your stuff safe.

Text: Yesterday I flew home from Jeddah via Doha on Qater Airways. On boarding the flight from Doha to Manchester it was quite chaotic in the forward economy cabin of the Airbus A330. Numerous families had unilaterally decided to seat themselves together regardless of their seat assignments. The poor FA spent 15 mins trying to get people into their correct seats. I reserved my usual aisle seat, but I had now been moved into a central aisle seat rather than my usual window aisle seat. I would hazard a guess this occurred to try and keep a family on the same row if possible, no big deal to be honest. However in my row was a mother and 2 children. The father of the family demanded rather than ask that I change seats with him, now if he'd been seated in business then fair enough, even accounting for his rather rude attitude. However he was seated in a centre seat behind me, I told him sorry but I dislike to being trapped in. He then became extremely rude, at which point I reported him to the FA. The FA had a word with him and he went off in Huff to his seat. Several hours later his young son looked at me and said " your the nasty bl@@dy man who wouldn't move" I guess that comment says it all really, clearly such language shouldn't come from a 3 yr old child. I have moved before to try and assist a family, as long as it's a similar seat close by then that's fine. This rather rude incident will definitely give me pause for thought in future. I think it was the overriding rude sense of entitlement that annoyed me. Regards Rick

Text: The reason of this email is to explain an unfortunate situation, me and other 10 passengers suffered at the Denpasar Airport on the 19 of December 2015. We arrived at the Denpasar airport, 19 of December 2015 with the flight VA65 from Sydney. Virgin. Now, we went to the transit Area in Denpasar and ask for Qatar Airways assistance. Nobody was there to do the checkin for transit passengers. We requested assitance to the airport personnel, but they did not help at all and told us that I we did not want to loose the connection flight, we had to do custom clearance, get our luggage and do the check in again at the Qatar desk. The personnel of the airport was disrespectful and with a total lack of customer service attitude. We had little time to decide and we finally made to the check in counter of qatar at the airport. When we did the check in, we were charged 200.000 rp which I think is completely wrong. 1) The airport tax was included in my ticket as the regulation changed on February 2015, Denpasar Airport tax was included , as I booked my flight during Sept 2015. 2) We were passenger in transit that did not get any help from Qatar or airport personnel and we wanted to take our flight. Passengers in transit should not pay the 200.000 rp. So, for the above stated, and because it was Qatar airways the carrier collecting the money, I am requesting the refund of it as I paid it twice. Another point to have in mind, right now I am at the Denpasar airport again, as a transit passenger, I arrived from Doha with Qatar airways and I am connecting to Sydey with Virgin. Virgin personnel was waiting for us on the transit counter of the airport of Denpasar, we did the check in and we did not pay for anything. So Virgin did his part on this situation, and Qatar did not.

Text: I have just return from one of the first Jetstar Flight's from Melbourne to Hawaii. I realise it was a budget flight but it does not mean all components of the flight should be poor. 1) We left over 2 hours late both going to and departing Hawaii. No staff members were informing the travellers about any delays. 2) Food was extremely poor especially for the cost of $25 per person per flight. Going to Hawaii we only had one choice for each meal: Dinner : Small size Chicken and Rice, Salad and a small chocolate . Breakfast: A meat pie (Yes, that is right) for breakfast and a ice cream bar. Not my idea of a breakfast meal at 3am. 3) The flight crew were nearly invisible, mostly talking to each other for the flight, as our rubbish stayed infront of us for atleast 1-1.5 hours. 4) In flight entertainment - was not handed out until at least 2 hour into the flight.
Annotator A Text: I have just return from one of the first Jetstar Flight's from Melbourne to Hawaii. Not my idea of a breakfast meal at 3am. 3) The flight crew were nearly invisible, mostly talking to each other for the flight, as our rubbish stayed infront of us for atleast 1-1.5 hours. 4) In flight entertainment - was not handed out until at least 2 hour into the flight.

Text: I've been comparing air-fairs and Aeroflot has always been the cheapest. I've avoided this airline for so long, because everybody I know told me to basically avoid Aeroflot unless absolutely necessary. I'm looking for a decent ticket for my fly between North Europe and Tokyo. The cheaper the better when it comes to price, but flight duration is more important to me. I just looked up and the fastest is with either Aeroflot or Finnair for this route. But there is a huge price difference (Aeroflot is offering one-way tickets for 1/3 of Finnair's price). My dilemma is that other routs are much longer than these. I don't want to have a layover in Continental Europe because that becomes a detour. But Finnair's prices are more expensive than other airlines that offer flights from Europe to Tokyo. I'm debating if it's safe to fly with Aeroflot... I've seen comments that say it's not that bad any more. But then again, I hear horrific stories. If you've flown with Aeroflot recently, I'd love to hear your story, especially between Moscow-Tokyo. Thanks!

Text: Think twice if you are travelling to the Maldives with Thomson. We were delayed 22hours last week and were late arriving at Male. We are both airline crew so were wise to the excuses they gave. They basically blamed snow, Spanish ATC and fog at Gatwick, all of which were lies! The airline were most unhelpful and had no reps at any point during the delay and lied to us about the reason for the heavy delay. Thomson couldn't even send a rep the next day to the Gatwick Hilton hotel with details of our departure time and on our return we should have been given a letter stating a technical problem for the delay not all the lies originally given. Despite asking for an address to write to for compensation via the rep in the Maldives she failed to give us a letter on why the delay happened, which we were entitled to and had to get a copy of this via a kind passenger. Because of the dishonesty and the fact they were spineless to confront their passengers we won't be using them again. This was by far the worst service I have received from any company and ruined a truly amazing holiday.

Text: We wanted to change our original round trip from Phoenix to Columbus to a three legged trip, from Phoenix to Columbus, then Columbus to Milwaukee to Rhinelander, then Rhinelander to Milwaukee to Phoenix. Our original reservations were on Southwest. Had to call customer service to change because our departure city was different, but the agent was able to help me, and we ended up with a $100 credit. Frontier is the only airline to fly nonstop from Columbus to Milwaukee, plus the only airline to fly out of Rhinelander. The first time I checked the fare was $175. Due to circumstances beyond my control, could not book it then. Last Thursday, ready to book, fare was $458! After I recovered from my heart attack, I explored other options and booked the lowest fare I could find, Delta thru Memphis, then Frontier to Rhinelander. (Knowing we'd have to pay a change fee if we had to change the Delta flights) Today I get an email from Frontier that the Rhinelander flight times have changed, and wouldn't you know, our flight from Memphis gets in at 4:20 and the flight to Rhinelander now leaves at 4:15! So now we have to stay overnight in Milwaukee!! Oh, and the Frontier agent's first response was to cancel our flights! He didn't care how we got to Land O'Lakes! Off the check the cost of renting a car for 10 days - and anyone know a decent cheap hotel with a shuttle at MKE?

Text: Just received an email from Trip Adviser offering me cheap flights to various destinations including Atlanta where I am flying to next month. Special cheap price with Last Minute, £440, not bad you think. Me to. Flights with KLM and Delta. Great. So next step check price with KLM, £476 plus a credit card charge, back to Last Minute, I mean that's a saving of £36. Go through booking process with Last Minute, £487 plus credit card charge. Now I've lost the £36 saving and they've added on £11. This example shows exactly how these online bookers work, headline price which doesn't exist rising to more than booking direct. Jackie Edited: 5:52 am, March 22, 2013

Text: My daughter and her boyfriend had a delay last year when flying home from Majorca. We followed all the guidelines and wrote requesting compensation for the 4 hour delay. Thomsons declined stating it was extra ordinary circumstances. Basically the flight from Majorca was delayed because the flight into majorca was delayed due to ongoing planned roundworks near to the airport causing "some staff and passengers to be late for the outgoing flight". These roadworks had been ongoing for more than 2 weeks prior to the date and therefore all staff/passengers should have been aware of the possibilities of delays and allowed extra time. The flight was also n a Sunday evening so this should have not been as much of a problem as it would have been at peak traffic times. After they declined my daughter wrote to the Spanish aviation authority and they agreed and advised compensation should be paid to the amount of é400 per passenger. Thomsons still refused and have refused to answer any further communication. She did all the communication via the online form - should we send in one last letter by post or should we proceed to the small claims court and in our opinions do you think she has a good chance of succeeding with the compensation claim.

Text: I hope I am posting in the correct forum... if not... please pardon me. My trip is: 7/12 and 13 Venice (via Milan) 7/14-15-16 Dublin 7/17-18-19-20 London Anyway, I have had a horrible horrible time trying to find a flight from Venice to Dublin...so I have decided to train it back to Milan and take Air France 1215 at 1pm connecting at CDG with a one hour five minute layover and then continuing on at 330pm to Dublin arriving at 4:35pm. My question is... do I have to go through immigration again at CDG since Ireland is not part of Schengen Agreement? I hate CDG airport but I have no way to avoid it. However, I don't want to get caught at CDG. The MXP-CDG flight arrives terminal 2F and CDG-DUB departs 2E (I might have those backwards) according to Air France's website. If anybody can help me on this connection, I would appreciate it. I have traveled through CDG many times but I have always been arriving from the US and not from within Europe so I really never paid much attention. Thanks.

Text: Back in October I purchased a R/T ticket on KLM web for a trip in March 2014 to Entebbe, Uganda. As part of the ticket I paid the fee for Economy Comfort seat for 4 legs (JFK-AMS, AMS-EBB, EBB-AMS, AMS-ATL). Since October I've routinely checked my itinerary online and up until yesterday everything was in order. Yesterday I checked and noticed that my Econ Comfort seats for the JFK-AMS and AMS-EBB legs were missing. I've contact KLM via email; they say their records only show the purchase for the two returning legs. I emailed them a copy of my receipt showing the purchase of all 4 seats and am waiting to hear back from them. My question is: does this happen often? I looked at the seat map and the flights appear to be very full. I'm concerned that if my seats have been re-sold or given away, I will be out of luck. It's not about getting a refund if that happens, I really want those seats. 24 hours of flying is tough but the KLM Economy Comfort product makes the trip much more pleasant.

Text: HI this has gotten to be a little pet peave of mine TSA and Customs are two seperate entities. when you enter USA . you go thru immigration to see if they will allow you entry. then you go thru customs where they look for contrabane. You do not go thru TSA. You only encounter TSA if you have an ownward domestic flight. when you leave USA or have a domestic flight then you go thru TSA security. Customs does not have access to the TSA keys to unlock bags. now I feel better that I got this off my chest. LOL
Annotator A Text: [HI ]this has gotten to be a little pet peave of mine TSA and Customs are two seperate entities.[ when you enter USA . you go thru immigration to see if they will allow you entry. then you go thru customs where they look for contrabane. You only encounter TSA if you have an ownward domestic flight. when you leave USA or have a domestic flight then you go thru TSA security. ]Customs does not have access to the TSA keys to unlock bags. now I feel better that I got this off my chest.[ LOL]

Text: British Airways has refused to reimburse us (wife and I) for expenses we incurred due to their cancellation of our flight. They offered $150 travel voucher each. Our costs are $470.44. We arrived at LHR at 10AM on May 24, 2013. BA advised that all flights were now canceled until 4PM. That meant our 3PM flight to CPH was canceled. We stood in line at BA Customer Service for ten hours, along with hundreds of others. Customer Service only opened 4 windows. As the hours crawled by - tempers flared. We got to the window at 8PM. No flights available this day, nor the next day - that would get us to CPH in time for the evening sailing of our cruise ship. We agreed to an 10AM standby for CPH, and a alternative code share routing that would get us close to the port where the ship would be on the second sailing day. We spent the night wandering Heathrow Airport, and retrieved our checked luggage. Not much sleep. Next morning - no luck at Standby. Rushed to the alternate plan - and flew up to Manchester UK. Then - rushed to another terminal to partner Lufthanza for a flight to Munich Germany. From there, Lufthanza toHamburg - where we arrived at midnight of May 25 - on a weekend night - without a hotel reservation. Taxied to a hotel (very lucky) and got a few hours sleep. May 26 - off to the train station: took train to Rostock, them S-bahn to Warnemunde. Hurray - that is where our cruise ship was now docked. We made it - No Thanks to British Airways - to whom we had submitted all our documentation. And - to be clear about all this: We are requesting Nothing for the Ten hours we futilely stood in line, for the stress and aggravation, for the no sleep, no food at the Heathrow airport. I think it is shameful that British Airways would subject their customers to such treatment - then, simply dismiss a polite request for reimbursement.

Text: Once again this past May BA 87 from LHR to YVR was cancelled due to a technical problem. Believe it or not the same thing happened to me on the same flight last June. I submitted an EU Claim with BA upon arriving home and the claim was rejected because the malfunctioning part was not scheduled to be replaced so the cancellation was deemed to be due to unforeseeable circumstances or something like that. Then much to my surprise last week I received an email from BA that they would be honouring the claim! Any idea why they might change their mind?? Just curious if anyone heard anything is all.

Text: Hi, Last month I booked a ticket for my wife and I to Las Vegas travelling on US Airways from Israel to LV. My passport is US, and hers is Israeli. I booked her ticket under the name shown on her Passport and Visa, we'll use Jane Doe. Her ticket is also booked under Jane Doe. However, shortly after booking the ticket she told me that she had her named in her passport to Jane Doe *my last name*. So her ticket is booked under Jane Doe. Her Passport says "Jane Doe" Her Visa says "Jane Doe" But when they turn to the next page, they'll see a "Change of Name" sticker reflecting the legal change to "Jane Doe + my last name". My question is, will she still be allowed to fly and/or should we expect major problems during our trip over this?

Text: Hi Just flew United Airlines. Boise to Bangkok cost $921 per person round trip. all flight's on time no baggage lost. I got upgraded to economy plus on 3 out of 4 international flight legs for no charge. meals were OK .service staff were pleasant. watched 8 movies i hadn't seen before. for me a typical boreing uneventful experience LOL but that is what I expect when I fly. I researched and made sure I flew on 777's not the old 747. the 777's have seat back screens. I am happy I got just what I payed for. so no complaints from me just satisfaction.

Text: We are arriving from Amsterdam, Netherlands, in Boston at 4:55pm. Our connecting flight to JFK leaves Boston at 6:16pm...at a different terminal within Logan. I am concerned with getting through Immigration, Customs, etc, and getting to the domestic terminal in this short time. Our travel agent, and the airlines state this is a 'legal' connection, and there is no other connecting flight later that night. I am concerned that this is a legal connection for a 25- year- old that can run, but I am nudging 70 and my fastest pace is slow. Am I being needlessly concerned? Any advice is appreciated - thank you.

Text: the flight is from new orleans to venice marco polo with plenty of time between stops in frankfurt and vienna. No fees like Expedia which charges $9.99. Many of these airlines give too tight times between the layovers, you need at least 2 hours for the passport control and to catch your flight. We have learned the hard way twice on british air to heathrow, they could not get the steplatter to open the plane and we missed our flight to venice and had to get a voucher to Gatwick. Our flight was found on Cheapoair. They have good prices but you do have to search I looked for 3 days to get the flight that gave us a chance that we don't have to run, we are seniors and would rather walk quickly or leisurely.

Text: I was travelling on one of the trains from Manchester to London in late July. We ordered train tickets over the phone for a specified time (12:45pm) and got on the trian only to find out that we were given the wrong boarding passes (2:45pm). We noticed this after a request to show our tickets half-way enroute to London. The conductor on that train was so rude and didn't listen to any of our complaints and ended up slapping us in the face with a fine of 101 British pounds ($190) each with my travel compainion. Our efforts to discuss the matter with Virgin trains were turned away. On the same car another lady had the same problem but was welcomed with police at the train station in Euston because she failed to pay the fine. We had tickets and it wasn't our fault that we had boarded the train at the wriong time- in my opinion! To be fined extra fees yet the train had extra empty seats left a lot to be desired. Anyone with advice on how to handle this matter? Please write me back on allen.63@netzero.com Back in the U.S I run out of luck with limited help from the Headquaters of Virgin Atlantic in CT. Thanks in advance.

Text: I've looked at the cabin bag allowance on the Emirates website and found the following: Economy Class passengers are permitted one (1) piece of carry-on baggage, either a handbag or laptop bag, subject to the following size and weight limitations: Handbag: 55 x 38 x 20cm (22 x 15 x 8 in.) I'm guessing that I am still allowed to bring a purse as well but just wanted to check if anyone has had any issues in the past. Most airlines seem to mention that you can have a carry-on and a personal item but it's not mentioned here. My husband usually brings his scuba regulator as his personal item and we've never had an issue with other airlines. The checked baggage allowance is more than we need but we don't like checking our regulators in case they get they get jostled too much and don't work. I checked mine once and had problems with it on the first dive so haven't checked it again since.

Text: I have recently switched to Clear Care, a hydrogen peroxide based contact lens solution, due to my eye care professional's recommendation. In a few months, this will be my first time traveling with it (by air). I have been hearing stories of TSA officers confiscating such solution in carry on baggage and not being able to negotiate citing medical necessity as a reason, even when the bottle is in compliance with the 3-1-1 limitation. The reasoning is that hydrogen peroxide can potentially be used as an explosive. I am wondering what people's experiences are with this? I have always known that it is best to have enough of your contact lens care material in your carry on baggage in case your checked baggage gets delayed. However, I now use exclusively Clear Care, and if that does not make it through TSA, I will be left with nothing upon arrival if my checked baggage gets delayed. I am planning to travel to an Asian destination, where there is almost no guarantee that I will be able to find the product for sale. I wear the overnight ortho-K lenses, thus I do not own a pair of prescription glasses, nor do I have any need for them.
